Thomas Dekker, ca. 1572-1632(1572?-1632) If it be not Good, The Diuel is in it. A Nevv Play, as it hath bin lately Acted, vvith great applause, by the Queenes Maiesties Seruants: At the Red Bull. Written by Thomas Dekker
Printed for I. T. And are to be sold by Edward Marchant (etc.) 1612

Play details
If it be not good, the Diuel is in it. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1612. Date first performed: 1611-16 Dec 2579.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by idREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Alphonso; King of Naples Bartervile; a merchant Duke of Calabria A Prodigal Erminhild; princess of Calabria Farneze; a gentleman Glitterback; a spirit Charon Rufman (disguised as Bohor) Lurchall Shacklesoule (disguised as Friar Rush) Pluto Minos Narcisso Octavio Prologue & Epilogue Scumbroth; a cook Rhadamanth Spendola Astolfo Jovinelli Brisco Alphege Omnes/multiple voices Prior SubPrior Pilgrim 1 Pilgrim 2 Soldier Scholar Seafarer Speaker 1 Speaker 2 Servant 1 Bravo Gentleman 1 Gentleman 2 Servant 2 Carolo Lucifer Fury Devil 1 Devil 2 Guy Fawkes Ravillac AEcus Iudg Puritan Friar Zany

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.l: Would it were a Custom that at all New-plays
The Makers sat on the stage, either with Bays
To have their Works Crowned, or beat in with Hissing,
Pied and bold Idiots, durst not then sit Kissing
A Muses cheek: Shame would base Changelings wean,
From Sucking the mellifluous Hypocrene:
Who write as blind-men shoot, by (Hap, not Aim,)
So, Fools by lucky Throwing, oft win the Game.
Phoebus has many Bastards, True Sons sew,
I mean of those, whose quick clear-eyes can view.
Poesies pure Essence, It being so divine,
That the Suns Fires, ( even when they brightest shine)
Or Lightning, when most subtly Ioue does spend it,
May as soon be approached, weighed, touched, or comprehended.
But it is with Poets now, as it is with Nations,
The ill-favouredest Vices, are the bravest Fashions.
A Play whose Rudeness, Indians would abhor,
Is it fill a house with Fish wives, Rare, They All Roar.
It is not Praise is sought for (Now) but Pence,
Though dropped, from Greasy-apron Audience.
Clapped may he be with Thunder, that plucks Bays,
With such Foul Hands, and with Squint-Eyes does gaze
On Pallas Shield; not caring (so he Gains,
A Crammed Third-Day, what Filth drops from his Brains.
Let Those that love Pans pipe, dance still to Pan,
They shall but get long Ears by it: Give me That Man,
Who when the Plague of an Impostumed Brains
(Breaking-out) infects a Theatre, and hotly reigns,
Killing the Hearers hearts, that the vast rooms
Stand empty, like so many Dead men's tombs,
Can call the Banished Auditor home, And tie
His Ear (with golden chains) to his Melody:
Can draw with Adamantine Pen, ( even creatures
Forged out of the Hammer, on tiptoe, to Reach-up,
And (from Rare silence) clap their Brawny hands,
To applaud, what their charmed soul scarce understands.
That Man give me; whose Breast filled by the Muses,
With Raptures, Into a second, them infuses:
Can give an Actor, Sorrow, Rage, Joy, Passion,
Whilst he again (by selfsame Agitation)
Commands the Hearers, sometimes drawing out Tears,
Then smiles, and fills them both with Hopes and Fears.
That Man give me: And to be such-a-One,
Our Poet (this day) strives, or to be None:
Lend not (Him) hands for Pity, but for Merit,
If he Please, he is Crowned, if Not, his Fate must bear it.

div1.stage: Enter (at the sound of hellish musick,) Pluto, and Charon.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What so.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I will be thy slave no longer.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What slave?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Hells drudge, her Galley-slave. I have worn
My flesh to the bones, bones marrowless, at the Oar
Tugging to waft to thy Stygian empire, Souls,
Which (but for Charon) never had come in Shoals,
Yet (swarmed they never so,) them on shore I set,
Hell gets by Charon, what does Charon get?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: His Fare.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Scurvy fare, I will first cry garlic.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: And make hell stink, as that does hither.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: If I do!
Some like that smell, my boat to shore I will pull;
Not work a stroke more.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Not touch a Scull.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I have no doings: Graves-end-barge has more,
And caries as good as any are in hell;
I fear the infernal rivers are frozen over
So few by water come: else the whores that dwell
Next door to hell, go about: besides, It is thought,
That men to find hell, now, new ways have sought,
As Spanirards did to the Indies. Pluto, mend
My wages, or row thyself.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Ugly, grumbling slave,
Have I not raised thy price? yet still dost crave?
Such bold brave beggars (heard off never before
Are thy fares now, they teach thee to beg more.
Thy fare was (first) a halfpenny, then the souls gave thee
A penny, then three halfpence, we shall have thee
(As market-folks on dearth,) so damned-deer,
Men will not come to hell, crying out they are here
Worse rack than they are in taverns: why dost howl for money?

sp.speaker: Cha:
sp.l: For money: I will have twopence for each soul
I ferry over, I am old, crazed, Stiff, and lamed,
That soul that is not worth twopence would it were damned.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Thou shalt not.

sp.speaker: Cha:
sp.l: I will it, or lie still,
If Charon fill hell, hell shall Charon fill:
For Ghosts now come not thronging to my boat,
But drop by one and one in; none of note
Are fares now: I had wont brave fellows to ply,
Who, (hacked and mangled) did in battles die.
But now these gallants which do walk hells Rounds,
Are fuller of diseases, than of wounds.
If wounded any take my boat, they roar,
Being stabbed, either drunk, or slain about some whore.
That is all the fight now.

sp.speaker: Prod:
sp.l: Charon.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Get thee gon:
That called for.

sp.speaker: Prod:
sp.l: Charon.

sp.speaker: Cha:
sp.l: Ball not. I will come anon.
Hags of hell gnaw thee with their foul furred-gums.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Pluto, no wonder if so few hither comes?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Why:
Gingerly: See See,
One of thine own promoters, (with hawks eyes,
That should for prey be watching) here suoring lies.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: With a mischief! cabined! a fury.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I will Ferret out more.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Another: look: dancing a bawd on his knee.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.l: I do enquire if rich bawds Carted be
On earth as well as poor ones: I sleep not Pluto.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Twist stronger-knotted whips, I will wake you (slaves!)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Two of thy Summers dead-drunk here too.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Charon.

div1.stage: Lurchall and another Spirit comes vp.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I come: If I must work, let these
Thy Prentices, ply their occupation,
To uphold hells Kingdom, more must work than one.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Ha; Are there whipping-posts for such as dwell
In Idleness on Earth, and yet shall Hell
(As if we took bribes here too,) let such pass!
I will have you rawde: Is not the world as it was?
Once mother of Rapes, Incests, and Sodomies,
Atheism, and Blasphemies, plump Boys indeed.
That sucked (our Dams breast) is she now barren? Ha!
Is there a dearth of villains?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: More now than ever?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Is there such penury of mankind Hell-hounds?
You can lie snoring.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Each Land is full of Rake-hells.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: But shoals of Sharks eat up the Fish at Sea.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Brave pitchy villains there.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Yet you playing here.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: No, No; most awful Pluto.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Were you good Hell-hounds, every day should be
A Symon-and-Iude, to crown our board with Feasts
A black-eyed-souls each minute: were you honest devils
Each officer in hell should have at least,
A brace of whores to his break-fast: above us dwell,
Devils braver and more subtle than in Hell.

sp.speaker: Omni.
sp.l: We will fill thy palace with them.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: I will try that: go:
Rufman, take instantly a Courtiers shape
Of any country: choose thine own disguise
And return swiftly.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Shackle-soul wear thou
A Friars grave habit.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Grumshall walk thou
In treble-ruffs like a Merchant.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So: it is done:

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: The bars of our litigious Courts had wont
To crack with thronging pleaders, whose loud din
Shook the infernal hell, as if it had been
An earth-quake bursting from the deep Abyss,
Or else Ioues thunder, thrown at the head of Dis
(The God of gold,) for hiding it below,
Thereby to tempt churls hither. Nor did we know
What a Vacation meant: continual term
Fattened hells Lawyers, and shall so again.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Command us.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Fly into the world:
As ye are in shapes transformed be so in name,
For men are out sides only: be you the same;
Hie thee to Naples, (Rufman), thou shalt find
A Prince there (newly crowned,) aptly inclined
To any bendings, least his youthful brows
Reach at Stars only, weigh down his loftiest boughs
With leaden plomets poison his best thoughts with taste
Of things most sensual; if the heart once wast
The body feels consumption; good or bad kings
Breed Subjects like them: clear streams flow from clear springs.
Turn therefore Naples to a puddle: with a civil
Much promising face, and well oiled play the court devil.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: I will do it in bravery: if as deep as hell,
Thy large ears hear a Land curse me, my part is played well.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Fly Shackle-soule.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: To the Friary,
Best-famed in Naples for strict orders: throw
What nets thou seest can catch them: Amongst them sow
Seeds of contention, or what ever sin
They most abhor, sweat thou to bring that in.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: A wolf in lamb skin leaps into the rout,
Bell, book, or candle cannot curse me out:
I will curse faster than they.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Do: Grumball.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Be thou a city-devil, make thy hands
Of Harpies claws, which being on courtiers lads
Once fastened, never let loose, the Merchant play,
And on the Burse, see thou thy flag display.
Of politic bankruptism: train up as many
To fight under it, as thou canst, for now is not any
That break, ( they will break their necks first) if, beside
Thou canst not through the whole city meet with pride,
Riot, lechery, envy, Avarice, and such stuff,
Bring them all in coached, the gates are wide enough.
The spirit of gold instruct thee: hence all.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Fly.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Stay, least you should want helpers at your calling
Any devils shall come, (Search hound, Tobacco spawling,
Vpshorten, Suckland, Glitterbacke, or any
Whom you shall need to employ, but call not many,
There is but few good in hell. And stay, remember
We all meet to hear how you prosper.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: The Tree
Blasted with Goblins, that about whose root
Five Mandrakes grow, in the Grove by Naples there,
Meet there.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We shall.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Our blessings with you bear.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Dread king of Ghosts, we will ply our thrift so well,
Thou shalt be forced to enlarge thy Jail of Hell.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Be quick that at best, let saucy mortals know,
How ever they sleep, there is one wakes here below.

div1.stage: Enter Alphonso (King of Naples) Crownde, wearing Robes Imperiall, Swordes of State, Maces, etc. being borne before him, by Octauio Astolfo, (2.vnckles) Narcisso, Iouinelli, Brisco, (Counts) with others, Counte Spendola meeting them.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: One of those gallant Troupes went forth to meet
Your admired Mistress (Erminhild the fair)
Hath left your Convoy with her on the way.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And brings glad news of her being here (this day)
Let Canons tell in Thunder her Arrival, Flourish.
When she is at hand ourself will meet her,

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: On.

div1.stage: Hee takes his Seate; All kneele.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Pray rise; until about our brows were thrown,
These sparkling beams, such adoration
Was not bestowed on us: whom does the knee
Thus lovely worship? this Idol, (Gold) or me?
Indeed it is the worlds Saint, if that you adore,
Go, pray to your coffers. None to us shall bow,
Give God your knees.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Whose own voice does allow
That Subjects should to those who are Supreme,
Bend, as to God, (all Kings being like to him)

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Thou wonder of thy time, I will pay no more
To thee of duty than has been before
And ever shall be paid to those sit High.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Pray mock not me with such Idolatry,
Kings, Gods are, (I confess) but Gods of clay,
Brittle as you are, you as good as they,
Only in weight they differ, (this poor dram)
Yet all but flesh and blood; And such I am.
If such, pray let me eat, drink, speak, and walk,
Not looked clean through, with superstitious eyes,
(Not starred at like a Comet.) As you go
Or speak, or feed, (un-wondered at) let me so.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Not Kings of Ceremony.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Uncle what then?
Still are they Kings.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: But show like common men.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Good uncle know, no Sun in this our Sphere,
Shall rule but We, let others shine as clear,
In goodness, None in greatness shall.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Blessed reign!
The Golden world is molding new again.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: All that I crave is this, and it is not new,
Pay unto Caesar only Caesar's due.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: We owe thee loyal hearts, and those we will pay,
Each minute (Mirror of Kings.)

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Mark, the old Lords promise their hearts, but no money.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Here are the Names of bold conspirators,
(Young Catilines, and far more desperate)
Who in your Fathers days kindled the fires
Of hot Rebellion.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Which are now burnt out.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Who knows that? embers in dead Ashes lie.
King, Set thy hand to this let Traitors die.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: It is fit you should do so.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Sound Policy.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Men many things hold fit,
That are not good,
A young Beginner and set up in blood!
(Butchers can do no more.)
Shall Records say
Being Crowned, he played the Tyrant the first day,
How should that Chronicler be cursed? your paper.
When such a fatal book comes in my sight,
I will with Vespasian wish I could not write,
Their bond is canceled. I forgive the debt,
See that at liberty, they all be set.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A Princely Act.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If wisely it is well done.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: That reign must boast,
Which mercy has begun.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Bear witness all, what pace the Chariot wheels
Of our new gilded Sovereignty shall run.

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: A main gallop I hope.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And here I vow to end as it is begun.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Heaven fill thee full of days,
But (being all told)
Ending no worse,
Their sum we will write in gold.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The course you will take dear Lord.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This: pray observe it.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p:
Call you this Coronation day? would I were in the
streets where the conduits run claret wine, there is some
good fellowship.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Each week within the year shall be a book
Which each day I will read over: I well may do it,
The book being but six leaves (six days,) the seventh
Be his that owes it;
Sacred is that and hie;
And who profanes one hour in that,
Shall die.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: How many will be left alive then this day fortnight?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: First, beat all Taverns down then, Souls are lost
(Being drowned in Surfeits) on that seventh day most.
Stay (best of Kings) mine own hand shall set down
What laws thou madest first day thou worest a Crown.
Begin, begin thy week.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Write Monday.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: So so, -- Monday.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p:
They say Monday is Shoemakers holiday, I will fall to
that trade.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I have writ it down my liege.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Peace, hearken to your lesson.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: That day, from morn till night, I will execute
The office of a Judge, and weigh outlaws
With even scales.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: That is more than grocers do.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The poor and rich man's cause
I will poise alike: It shall be my chief care
That bribes and wrangling be pitched over the bar.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: We shall have old breaking of necks then.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Down with that first.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: O for a pen of gold!
You will have no bribes.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Yet term time all the year!
A good strong law, suite cannot now cost dear.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Have you done?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I am at bribes, and wrangling done presently.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p:
We must all turn pettifoggers, and in stead of gilt
rapiers, hang buckram bags at our girdles.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p: All my clients, shall be women.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p:
Because they are easiest fetched over: there is something
to be gotten out of them.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Thy monday's task is done: what is next?

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Sunday if the week goes backward.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tuesdays we will sit to hear the poor-man's cries,
Orphans and widows: our own princely eyes
Shall their petitions read: our progress then
Shall be to hospitals which good minded men
Have built to pious use, for lame, sick, and poor
We will see what is given, what spent, and what flows over
Churls (with Gods money) shall not feast, swill wine,
And fat their rank guts whilst poor wretches pine.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: This is a brave world for beggars, if it hold.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Poor wretches pine, So are they left: to the next.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Wednesdays We will spend.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: In fish dinners.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Of foreign states, treat with ambassadors,
Hear them and give them answers. Thursday, for wars.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p:
That is well: better be together by the ears, than to go
halting to hospitals.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Our Neapolitane youths (that day) shall try
Their skill in arms, poor scorned Soldiers
Shall not be suffered beg here (as in some lands)
Nor stoop slave-like to Captain's proud commands,
Starve, and lie nasty, when the selfsame pay,
The Soldier fights for, keeps the Leaders gay.
Nor shall he through ice and fire make gray his head,
Wear out new Moons, only to earn his bread,
Wade up to the beard in torrents; and be drowned
All save the head; march hard to meet a wound,
In the very face, and even his heart-strings crack,
To win a town, yet not to cloth his back:
And the black storm of troubles being gon,
Shunned like a creditor, not looked upon,
But as court-pallats (when bright day draws nigh)
Rolled up in some dark corner is thrown by.
Uncle write that.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Fast as my pen can trot.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p:
What a number of tottered rogues will be turned into brave
fellows a this new change of the moon

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: The braver they are, the sooner are mercers undone.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Soldiers are down too.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: down with Learning next.
For friday shall be spent in the reverend Schools,
Where we will sift bran from flour, (hiss babbling fools,
But crown the deep-brained disputant) none shall hold
Three or four Church-livings (got by Symonious gold)
In them, to fat himself as in a sty,
When greater Scholars languish in beggary:
And in thin thread-bare cassocks wear out their age,
And bury their worth in some by vicarage:
This we will see mended.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Tithe pigs you will smoke for this.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: So set it down.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Scholars languish in beggary -- So:
Thy fridays law is writ; for Saturday, what?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye marry sir, All our cares now for that.
Well to begin, and not end so were base,
The winning of the gold crowns each man's race.

div1.stage: Narcisso stepping in before in the Scene, Enters here.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: Sir, there is a stranger newly arrived your court,
And much importunes to behold your Highness.

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: Of goodly presence.

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: Let him see us.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: The powers that guide me, guard thee, I have heard thy name
In regions far hence, where it does resound
Louder than here at home; to touch this ground
I have passed through countries, into which none here
Would willingly sail I think, and with me bring,
My love and service, which to your grace I tender.

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: What are you, and whence come you?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: From Heluetia.

sp.speaker: Spen:
sp.l: What hell says he?

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: Peace you shall know hot hell time enough.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p:
I am an Heluetian born, the house from which I
am descended, ancient and well known to many princes:
Bohor is my name.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: S'wounds! Bohor! has struck two of my teeth out with his name,

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: A Shalcan Tartar being my grandfather
Men call me Shalkan Bohor. About the world
My travails make a girdle (perfect round:)
So that, what wonders Kings on earth ever found
I know, and what I know, Is yours.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Brave Heluetian,
We give you thanks and welcome: your arrival
Is fair and to our wish, of all those days
Which Time sets down, to number up a week,
Every day have we tasked; save only one,
How in these courts of Kings (through which you have gon,)
Do Princes wast their hours?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: How but in that,
For which they are born Kings? (Pleasure:) every man's aim,
Is to hit pleasure: only it is changed in name,
That is all the difference; Are Kings Tyrants? Blood
Is then their pleasure: thirst they after wars!
Ambition tickles them: that for which man most cares,
Good or bad, it is his pleasure, and to gain it,
His soul must compass it though hell restrain it:
To this mark all men's thoughts, Creation drew,
That all might strive for a thing, that is got by few:
Who are those few but Kings? and it is fit they
Should have it, because true pleasure does soon decay.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How like you his counsel?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Rarely.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: What ruffians this?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Bohor thou hast warmed our young blood; All cares of state;
Shall that day sleep, to ourself we will Saturday have,
Pleasure (the slave of Kings shall then be our slave,
Lords let there be a proclamation drawn,
What man soever (strange or native born,)
Can feast our spleen, and heighten our delight,
He shall have gold and be our favourite.
Tilts, tourneys, masques, plays, dancing, drinking deep
Though ere noon all Naples lie dead-drunk asleep.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: How King?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: We will have it so uncle.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Down with that too.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Print Saturday in great text letters.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Well, well, it shall.
Our swan turns crow, poisoned with one drop of gall.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I will have this proclamation forthwith drawn.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: And publish all the days.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: And Saturday.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Especially that at large if you can in red,
like a Dominicall letter.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Go see it done.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: My task.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why sigh you? Of six days would you not spare me one?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p:
Thine own laws from thine own mouth, we will
proclaim, if thine own words thou elatest, be it thine own
shame.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Your long expected happiness is arrived,
The princess of Calabria.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou crownest me again?
Dear uncle, honoured Lords, with our whole court
Honour her hither; I am rapt with Joy,
And lost till I behold her: fetch me my love.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I fear deep whirl pools though it run smooth above.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: To our worthy friend your welcomes.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: But pray Sir tell us, mean you that we indeed
Shall have but one playing day through the whole week?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: All Iouinelli, we will be Jovial all.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Till Saturday came, we lived in terrible fear.
Thank Bohor, who your dead spirits up did rear.

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: Had I (as first I did begin) gon on,
I like a Schoolboy should have worn my crown,
As if I had borrowed it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Had been most vile.

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: I will be a Sea, (boundless.)

sp.speaker: Spen:
sp.l: Thou art a sun,
And let no base clouds muffle thee.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Brave Kings all!
Crown, Sceptre, Court, City, Country, are at your call.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: There spake young Ioue indeed.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: The tide now turns.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: And now we will swim.

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: And laugh, though the whole world mourns.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Tantara, hey.

div1.stage: Enter Octauio and Astolphe, vshering Erminhild, attended by Ladies and others.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: Call up your lustiest spirits: the Lady is come.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: O my earthly bliss! embraces! kisses! how sweet
Are you to parted Lovers when they meet?
That entertainment which the Duke your Father,
Lent royally (late to me, ) I now can pay
At a Kings charge: to our Neapolitane Court,
None (brightest Erminhild can come longed for
More than yourself. ) You have stolen upon us (Lady)

sp.speaker: Erm:
sp.l: You have good Law against me, (playing the thief)
Your Grace may keep me prisoner.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: In these Arms;
From whence not Ioue shall ransom thee; We Twain
Will wed, and bed, and get a Prince shall reign
In Naples bravely, when we both lie dead:
Till then, Pleasures wings, to their full breadth be spread.

div1.stage: Enter Scumbroth, ringing a Bell; Alphege, a Fryer, &" Shackle-soule, in a Friers weede, with cloth to lay.

sp.speaker: Scum.
sp.p:
A mangier, a mangier, a mangier, I must needs have
a mangy voice, when I do nothing but ball for a company of
hungry Scabs; a mangier.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You must be nimble Rush.

sp.speaker: Sha:
sp.p: As a drawer in a new Tavern, first day the bush is hung up.

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.p: A mangier, a manger, a mangier.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p:
So: the Lord Priors napkin here, there the Subpriors:
his knife and case of pick-tooths thus: as for the covent,
let them lick their fingers in stead of wiping, and suck
their teeth in steed of picking.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: What other duty Sir, must I call mine?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p:
As you are novice, you are to say grace demurely,
wait on the Priors Trencher soberly, steal away a mouthful
cunningly, and munch it up in a corner hungrily. Ply
your office, Rush.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.l: Thanks good Friar Alphege: yes, Shackle-soule will play
The task he is set to: Devils never idle lie:
Friar Rush! ha, ha: ye have now an excellent quire,
To sing in hell, the Devil and the Friar.

div1.stage: Enter Prior, Subprior, Alphege, Hillary, Rush, and other Friers. All sit: dishes brought in before.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Where is Rush, our Junior Novice?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Here Lord Prior.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Stand forth, and render thanks.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Hum, hum:
For our bread, wine, ale and beer,
For the piping hot meats here:
For broths of sundry tastes and sort,
For beef, veal, mutton, lamb, and pork.
Green sauce with calves head and bacon,
Pig and goose, and crammed-up capon.
For past raised stiff with curious art,
Pie, custard, florentine and tart.
Baked rumps, fried kidneys, and lam-stones,
Fat sweetbreads, luscious marrowbones,
Artichoke, and oyster pies,
Buttered Crab, prawns, lobsters thighs,
Thanks be given for flesh and fishes,
With this choice of tempting dishes:
To which proface: with blithe looks sit ye,
Rush bids this Covent, much good do it ye.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: How darest thou mock us thou ill nurtured slave?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Contemnest thou our order and religious fare?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: He has spoken treason to all our stomachs.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Down with the villain.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: If we feed so vile a wretch.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thrust him out at gates.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I do conjure you by my hallowed beads
To hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Canst thou excuse thyself?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Alas (my Lord) I thought it had been here
As in the neighbouring Churches, where the poorest Vicar
Is filled up to the chin with choice of meats,
Yet seeks new ways to whet dull appetite,
As there with holy spells men's souls they cherish,
So with delicious fare, they themselves nourish.
Nor want they argument for sweet belly-cheer
To prove it lawful.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Most profane and fearful.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: But since your order (pious and reverend)
Tied to religious fasts, spends the sad day
Wholly in meagre contemplation,
I absolution beg on both my knees,
For what my tongue offended in: alas! poor Rush
( See it by his cheeks) eats little: I can feed
On roots, and drink the water of the Spring
Out of mine own cup: make an Anatomy
Of my most sinful carcass: then pardon me.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thy ignorance is thy pardon, we believe thee.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Gratias reuerenda domine Prior.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: But do our brethren in parts more remote,
Feed so delicious sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Rush cannot lie.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thou falsely dost accuse those holy men.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: How can it stand with their profession?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thou sayst (vile young man) they have arguments
To prove it lawful gluttonously to feed.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Rush, answer the Sub-prior.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p:
Audite fratres, they do not only prove it lawful,
but make it palpable, that he who eats not good meat is
damned.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Benedicite.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: What shall become of all us then?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thou art distracted, whence canst thou force argument?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: From silly reason, would you hear me speak?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Speak freely and be bold, listen.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: He that eats not good meat is damned: Sic Dispute. ,/foreign>
If he that feeds well hath a good soul, then e Contra.
No, he that feeds ill, hath a bad and a poor soul.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p:
And so consequently is damned, for who regards poor
souls? and if they be not regarded they are cast forth, and
if cast forth, then they are damned.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: I deny your minor, he that feeds well hath a good soul.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p:
Sic probo: the soul follows the temperature of the
body, he that feeds well hath a good temperature of body,
Ergo, he that feeds well hath a good soul.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: A full and edifying argument.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: I deny that the soul follows the temperature of the body.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p:
Anima sequitur temperatura Corporis , It is a principle,
and contra principia non est Disputandum ,
sp.l: All we.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: It is most apparent.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: O most learned Rush!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: A shallow Sophister, hear me farther.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p:
Sub Prior, we will hear the rest disputed at our leisure:
you take too much upon you.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Shall I take this upon me my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p:
Hence with this trash, we have too long forborne to
taste heavens blessings fully, which to our duty had more enabled
us, Rush thou art some Angel.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Rather some devil sent to bewitch our souls.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Sub-prior no more.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I must speak, hear me brethren,
Shall we (bound by solemn oaths) to abjure the world,
And all her sorceries: to whom night and day
Are as one hour of prayer? whose temperance makes us
Endure what fulfilled belly Gods admire;
Shall we (by zealous patrons) tide to observe
Dirges and Requiems for their peaceful souls,
In gluttonous riot bury sacred alms!
Turn Sanctimonious zeal and Charity
To loathsome surfeit? and those well-got goods
Our benefactors saved, by their own fasts
And moderate living, shall we feed upon
Full-gorging us till we vomit? fore-fend it heaven!
By all the Saints, by him first taught our order
What temperance was, here shall poor Clement feed,
Till his over-wearied life, takes her last leave
Of this all tempting world where all sins breed.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: How is this? are you become our confessor?
Best thrust us out at gates, lock up the Cloister,
And call in whom you like: be you the Prior.
Speak are you agreed, Rush be our master-cook?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: You have my voice.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Do you all consent?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Yes, all.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: First send this fiend to banishment.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: We have most voices on our side.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You may;
Alas! most men covet still the broadest way.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Give Rush his charge then, Scum: you must resign.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: With a good maw, I shall have a fatter office to be his scullion.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Worthy Lord Prior, hear me yet,
I must not my profession let,
To Scumbroath, what I know I will teach,
To make candles, Jellies, leach,
Syrup of violets, and of roses,
Cowslip salads, and kick-choses,
Preserve the apricot, and cherry,
Damson-pear-plum, raspberry;
Potatoes eke if you shall lack,
To corroborate the back:
A hundred more shall Rush device,
And yet to early matins rise,
Our ladies office, sing at prime,
At even-song, and at compline time.
Chant Anthems, Aniversaries, Dirges,
And the doleful de profundis.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thou shalt not change thy order: Sirrah, cook,
From Rush take lessons against night, for fare
Abundance and delicious.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
I shall be greedy to learn of him sir, since your lordship
is turned, our very Iack and his spits shall turn too,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: What men are these?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Welcome good holy father.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Thanks reverend master.

sp.speaker: 1, Pil.
sp.l: Blessed sir, according to the Churches' rite
We (Pilgrims, to Ierusalem bound) this night
Desire repose, and pious charity
In your most holy Convent.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: You are most welcome.
Alphege, go lead them in.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: By no means.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: It is mortal sin.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O black impiety!

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.l: How? sin to feed religious votaries!

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Rather to nourish idle vagabonds:
The Clergy of other lands, have with much piety
And thrift destroyed those drones, that lazily
Live eating up the labours of the bee.
A churchman there cares but to feed the soul,
He makes that charge his office. Alsmisdeeds! alas!
They through the Lawyers hands are fittest to pass.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Can you hear this Devil?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Besides my reverend Lord,
sp.p:
These manderers here are spies, and soon bear word to Princes
ears of what they hear and see.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Ha Rush! thou speakest right.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Damned iniquity!

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Hence with those runagates.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l:
Come,
hence.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O had mine eyes dropped out ere seen this day.
Stay comfortless poor souls, my pitying tears
Shall speak what my tongue dares not, here holy men,
You never shall say when next we meet again,
Friar Clement to the hungry grutched his meat,
Or to the weary pilgrim lodging, this makes you eat,
And when you have relieved your fainting limbs,
Commend me in your prayers, and midst your hymns
Thus wish, that he who did your Journey further,
May never live, to break his holy order.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Old superstitious dotard; beat hence these beggars.

sp.speaker: 1. Pil.
sp.l: Many old men's curses will on his soul be spent,
Who thus defaces, Charities monument:

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p:
I told you they were curs, that cease to bark, no
longer than you feed them.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Friar thou speakest right:
Make haste with fare delicious, we will crown the night.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Ha ha, laugh Lucifer, dance grim fiends of hell,
Of souls thou judge must, but most terrible,
I must exact a double pay from thee,
Never hadst thou Journey man deserved such fee,
Let me cast up my reckonings, what I have won
In this first voyage: Charity! she is undone:
Fat gluttony broke her back: next her stepped in
Contention (who shakes Churches) now the sweet sin
(Sallow lechery,) should march after: Avarice,
Murder, and all sins else, hell can device,
I will broach: the head is in, draw the body after,
Begin thy feast in full cups, end in slaughter
That damnedest fury: O, but Friar Clement is free!
True: hast no snare to entrap him: let me see.
He is old, choake him with gold; hold on thy Revels,
Pluto makes Sackle-soule president of Devils.

div1.stage: Enter K. Octauio, Narcisso, Iouinelli, Spendola.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What picture is that (Uncle Octauio?)

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The picture of thy state, (drawn by thyself, )
This is that book of statutes, were enacted
In the high Parliament of thy royal thoughts
Where wisdom was the speaker. And because
Thy subjects shall not be abused by laws
Wrapped up in characters, crabbed and unknown,
These thine own language speak.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hang them up uncle.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: What says the King?

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: You must hang up the laws.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Like cob-webb in foul rooms, through which great flies
Break through, the less being caught by the wing, there dies.
No no, thy laws I will fix full in thy sight,
(Like sea-marks,) that if this great ship of sway
And kingly ventures, loose her constant way.
In the bottomless gulf of state, (beaten by the storms
Of youthful folly, raging in monstrous forms)
She may be saved from sinking and from wrack,
(Steered by this compass, for the points of it
Shall guide her so, on rocks she cannot split.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You are our careful pilot in this voyage
Of Government, be you our Admiral.
Wisdom and Age being props, realms seldom fall.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Oraculous is thy voice.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: How now count Brisco?
Methinks I read a comedy in thy looks.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: Has met some merry painter, he is drawn so lively.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Come count your news.

sp.speaker: Bris:
sp.l: I shall bestow them freely:
The physicke of your proclamation works:
Your gilded pills (rolled up in promises
Of princely favours to his wit, who highest
Can raise your pleasures) slip so smoothly down
Your Subjects throats, that all ( upon a sudden)
Are loosely given.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: How? loosely given? why count?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Name but what sport, your Highness would have Acted
I am prologue to it: your court must have more gates
To let in ruffling Saturday: without (now) waits
Music in some ten languages: each one swears
(By Orpheus fiddle-case) they will tickle your ears
If they can do it with scraping.

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.l: There is seven score Noise at least of english fiddlers.

sp.speaker: Io:
sp.l: Seven score! they are able to eat up a city in very scraps.

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.p:
Very base-vial men most of them: besides whole
swarms of welsh harps, Irish bag-pipes, Jews trumpets,
sp.l: And french kits, All these made I together play:
But their damned caterwauling, frighted me away.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: These sports to please
A Princes eyes?

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.l: How like you then of these?
The city-waterbearers (trimly dight)
With yellow oaken-tankards (pinned upright)
Like brooches in their hats; In their fresh loves
A may-game bring, All, wearing dog-skin gloves.
Made not to shrink in the wetting.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Bid these poor men drink well, and so be gon.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: What will you have then?
Will you see the Turners show, bravely prepared
With colours, drums, and guns (with rust half marred
Bearing that, of which they long have been deprived.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Their daring Giant, (newly reuvived)

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: For Ioues sake let us see that.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: O fie (Prince) fie!
In thy court painted monsters, they come not here,
Ride forth, thou shalt meet Giants everywhere.
Methinks (young Lords) your souls being new refined
With beams of honour, should not be declined
To sports so low and vulgar: but since the King
Of birds (the Eagle) lets you spread a wing
So near his own, you should put up such game
As fits an Eagle, and pursue the same.
And not like ravens, kites, or painted Jays
So are high, yet light on dunghills, for stinking preys.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Old Lord you rave.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: What sports would you devise?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Most fit for Kings. Were I (before his eyes)
To present objects, they should all be rare,
Of Romane triumphs, laden with the spoils of war:
Or Lions, and wild-Bears killed by active force:
Or sea-fights: or land-battles on foot, or horse:
Such sights as these, kindle in Kings brave fire,
And meeting spirits that dare mount, mount them higher,
Where apish pastimes lay our souls down flat,
Grovelling on earth, base and effeminate.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: I have bowls of this bias too, for your Lordships alley.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Trundle them out before him.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: The wooden-leg Soldier,
Waits to present you with his show of war.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Aye marry my liege.

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.l: The Scholar has his device, the Mariner his.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: These are Kings sports indeed.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Will you see these?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Faith be it so; because we will now rather please
Our uncle than ourself, pray fetch in these.
The rest cashier.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l:
Send the fiddlers
merrily home.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: And yet pay them scurvily! it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: And bid the water-bearers cleanse the city
There is many a foul thing in it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Marshall them in.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: I will fetch these worthy spirits in myself.

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.l: No, no, we will aid you sir.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: March: and give us room.

sp.speaker: Ki:
sp.l: 'sdeath! if these doting gray-beards might have their wills,
We never shall have ours: let us cross them
As they cross us.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: How, how!

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: Their Ningles bring in, abuse with scurvy jest,
Be it never so good.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: If Ninies bring away the Nest.

sp.speaker: Ki:
sp.l: Teach Iouinelli and Brisco when to give fire.

div1.stage: Enter Octauio, Iouinelli, Brisco, Rufman, the Souldier, Scholler, Mariner.

sp.speaker: Sol:
sp.l: I am a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: We know that by your legs.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Does my stump grieve you?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Not if you bestir your slumps nimbly sir.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: What hot shot is this?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: A Soldier sir: that is all:
That is more than sir I think you dare be S'wounds! baffled
For my limbs lost in service! your noble father
Has clapped this buff jerkin, when this Stump of wood
Has up to the knee stuck three hours in french blood:
When such as you, with your Spangled roses, that day
Bravely bestirrred their heels, and ran away:
I will stand to it, I.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: With one leg.

sp.speaker: Sol:
sp.l: Yes: with one.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Young Lords, thus to scorn Soldiers, it is ill

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Uncle, here is no man scorns them; must we be braved
By a staring fellow, for a little fighting? go.

sp.speaker: Sol:
sp.l: Fighting! I cannot halt I, but speak plain,
No King on earth baffles me, I would baffle again,
The whole race of great turks, had them in the field: I have brought
With me a hundred Soldiers, (old Servitors)
Poor as myself in clothes; pick out five hundred
Of such silk-stocking men, if they beat us, hang us,
'sblood if we toss not them, hang us again: a fort
We have built without, and manned it, this was the sport
A Soldier wood have given thee: my one hundred
Had taught thee all the rules in the School of war.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: All this I will read without maim, wound or scar.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: What say you to an Engine, that at once
Shall spoil some thirty men?

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: Thirty men! nothing.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: If nothing! hast thou been beat for this? farewell.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: I can fetch twenty scriveners have done more
With a bare goose-quill.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Mayst thou but live, to need a Soldiers arm,
That laughed to see him bleed.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: You have lost the day sir, for your Soldiers fly.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Fly to the devil let them.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Your leaders before.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: You fight all under one colours? do you not?

sp.speaker: Scho.
sp.l: Sir: these pleasures to the King which I prefer,
Flow from Ioues brain.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: Heyda! here is one has beaten out Ioues brains.

sp.speaker: Seap.
sp.l: Would I had thee hung up at our maine kit.

sp.speaker: Sch:
sp.l: No Sir Ioues brain, (Minerua queen of wit)
If all the Muses and the Arts can fit
With their high Tunes, such choice and Princely ears,
Apollo (Father to them all) -- appears --

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.p:
Apollo was an Ass; he let a wench whom he loved to
be turned into a Bay-tree, and now she is glad for a penny to stick
Ale-house-windows, and wind dead corpses.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Let Apollo go and lie with his own Daughters.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Are you a Scholar Sir?

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p:
A school-master as I take it, and comes to present a very
pretty show of his scholars in broken Latin.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Can we be dumb and see this?

sp.speaker: Sch:
sp.l: O hapless Learning!
Fly and complain, to Heaven (where thou wert born)
sp.p:
That thou ( whom Kings once nursed,) art now their
scorn.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: How blows the wind Sir?

sp.speaker: Seaf:
sp.p: Wind! is Nor-Nor-West.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: To hoist your sails up too, I think it is best.

sp.speaker: Sea:
sp.p:
A black Gust is coming: up a low-there hey: A
young-man up to the Top-mast-head, and look-out: stand to
your Sails: stand to your Top-sails: let go your Harriers,
let go, amain louerie amain, quick, quick, Goodfellows.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.p: He is mad.

sp.speaker: Sea:
sp.p:
Who is at Helm? bear up hard: and hard up: and
thou beest a man bear up; Starboard, Port-again: off with
your Drabblers, and your Banners; out with your Courses:
Ho, -- I spy two Ships yonder, that yaw too and again,
they have both sprung a Leak, I think the Devil is
sucking Tobacco, here is such a Mist: out with your boat,
and you Besmen, cut-down Mast-by-the-board; bear up,
sp.l: I am a Blunt-fellow you see, All I say is this,
You that scorn Sea-men, shall a Sea-man miss.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Now by my life I have patient stood too long.
To see rich merit and love, paid with base wrong:
Learning! and Arms! and Traffic! the triple wall
That fortifies a Kingdom, race them down All!
This Seaman, ( he that dear stearnes his bread)
Had rigged and manned four Galleys bravely furnished,
With Soldiers, Rowers, and Fireworks for a Sea-fight.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You are full of Squibs too, pray go fire them all.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Must I be then cashiered too? marry and shall.
To save thy sinking Honour, I will send hence
These men with thanks, with praise, and recompense.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Pray do.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Brave Shalcan-Bohor, all this while
Our eye has followed yours, and seen it smile,
(As it were in scorn) of what these men could do,
Which made us slight them off; to engross you
(Our best and richest prize:) in the Courts of Kings
Through which you have passed, you have seen wonders, show them.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: I shall at opportune hours. If your Grace
Arride the toys, they bragged of (Fireworks,
And such light-stuffs) Sit fearless without danger
Of murdering shot, which villains might discharge
In (idle counterfeit Sea-fights) you shall see
At opening of this hand, a thousand Balls
Of wildfire, flying round about the Air -- there. Fireworks on Lines.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Rare, Rare.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: It is excellent, 'sdeath from whence flew they?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Hell, I think.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p:
Hell! Nay, if any that are in Hell, skip up ever so nigh
Heaven, as these Devils that spit fire did, I will drink nothing
but Gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Ha, ha, a trifle this. Your Scholar there,
Come with his Arts and Muses shallow, leaden brain,
Your swaggering Soldier, lead a tottered train
Of ruffianly Boore-hallers: I noted all
These feasts for Kings: in the garden of variety
The vast world! you are starved midst you satiety,
Pluck no one Apple from the golden Tree,
But shake the fruit of every pleasure down.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thanks Bohor; why else wears a King his Crown?
Shalcan, all Naples shall not buy thee from me.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Nor you and these from me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Ask what thou wilt have
But to stay here.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Lo, this is all I crave.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thou hast our fast embraces.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Swift as man's thought,
Various delights shall be each minute born,
And die as fast that fresh may rise; we scorn
To serve up one dish twice; be it never so rare,
Will you that against tomorrow I prepare
A Feast of strange Mirth for you?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Dear Bohor do.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: I shall; Nor do I thus your love pursue,
With servile hopes of Gold, I need it not:
If out the jaws of Hell Gold may be got
Black Arts are mine to do it; and what delights
Those work be yours.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thou art gracious in our sight.

div1.stage: A Table is set out by young fellowes like Merchants men, Bookes of Accounts vpon it, small Deskes to write vpon, they sit downe to write Tickets, Lurchall with them.

sp.l: Come fellow Lurchall write.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Fuh, Stay not for me,
I shall outgo you all.
I hold five Crowns,
We all leave you behind us.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Done; but I
sp.p:
Must not leave you behind me; what pains a poor Devil
takes to get into a Merchant? he is so civil,
sp.l: One of Hell must not know him, with more ease
A Devil may win ten Gallants, than one of these,
Yet a Merchants wife, before these ten is won
To entertain her Devil, if Pride be one.
But Lurchall, now thou art in, and for years bound,
To play the Merchant, play him right: thou hast found
A Master, who more villainy has by heart,
than thou by rote; See him but play his own part,
And thou dost Hell good service; Barteruile,
there is in thy name a Harvest makes me smile.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Lurchall:

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: My master calls.

div1.stage: Men too and fro bring in Bags, & haue Bills.

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: O, art there?
This day twixt one and two a Gallants bound
To pay four hundred Crowns to free his Lands
Fast mortgaged to me, Lurchall, got thee up hie
Into my Turret, where thou mayst espy
All comers every way; if by thy guess,
Thou seest the Gull make hither.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So Sir.

sp.speaker: Barr.
sp.l: That, his Hour
Lie gasping, at the last Minutes; let him beat at door,
Within I will beat his heart out.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: I will let him stand.

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: Do, take my Watch, go faster. All his Land
Is summed with these two Figures, ( two and one )
At past one, (his,) strike but two, it is mine own.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: I will turn the wheels: and spin the hours up faster

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: The City-clocks then strike, and kill thy Master.
Would all the City Sextons, at my cost
Were drunk this day four hours.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: Troth so would I,
And we their Iackes at the Clock house.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: We would strike merrily.
Fly up to the top at the house,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: There sir, I will sit,
And croak like a Raven, to damn thee in hells pit.

div1.stage: Barteruile set amongst his men reading a long scroll.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How goes this month?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Much shorter than the last.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Weddings this month twelve thousand: not worth the scoring,
But think there is little marrying, we have so much whoring.
Grinding mills so much-used; about the city
Such grinding, yet no more money; suites in law,
Full brought to an end this month, no more but ten:
This law will beggar us: had I the bags again,
I bought this cumbrous office with, the King
Should make his best off it: he that did farm it before
Had it for less than I, yet received more.
How much remains of the salt tribute due?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: seven thousand Crowns.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That is well: a savoury sum:
These our Italian tributes, were well devised,
Methinks it is fit a subject should not eat
But that his Prince from every dish of meat
Should receive nourishment: for (being the head)
Why should he pine, when all the body is fed?
Besides, it make us more to awe a King,
When at each bit we are forced to think on him.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: What payment is this?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
The pension of the Stews, you need not untie it, I
brought it but now from the sealers office: there is not a
piece there, but has a hole in it, because men may know
where it was had, and where it will be taken again: bless your
worship? Stew-mony sir, Stew-Prune cash sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They are sure, though not the soundest pay masters,
Read what is the sumane.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: But bare two hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
They are bare crowns indeed sir, and they came
from Animals and vermin that are more bare: we that are
clerks of these flesh-markets have a great deal of rotten
mutton lying upon our hands, and find this to be a sore
payment.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Well, well, the world will mend.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: So our surgeons tell them every day; but the pox of ammendment I see.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Do not your gallants come off roundly then?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Yes sir, their hair comes off fast enough, we turn away
cracked french crowns every day. I have a suite to your
worship in behalf of all our dealers in small wares, our free
whores sir, you know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: If your whores are known, what is thy suite?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
I should have brought a petition from them, but that
it is put off sir, till cleansing-week, that they may all be able to
set to their hands, or else a whores mark.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Well, well, what is their request?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Marry sir, that all the she-tobacco-shops, that creep
up daily in every hole about the City, may be put to silence.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why pray thee honest fellow?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
I thank your good worship, I had not such a sweet
bit given me this seven years, honest fellow: marry sir I will open
to you your suppliants cases: they that had wont to spend a
crown about a smock, have now their delight dog-cheap,
but for spending one quarter of that money in smoke: besides
sir, they are not contented to rob us of our customs only,
but when their pipes are foul with spitting and drivelling
in those foresaid shops, they have no place to burn them in,
but our houses.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Draw their petition, and we will see all cured.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Let a frost come first sir: I thank your venerable
worship; the pox gnaw out so many small guts as have paid
thee crowns.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The tide is against you sir, the crowns are come.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How goes my watch?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: As most watches use to go sir, sleepily, heavily.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: Not reached to one yet; wert thou to be hanged,
The hour had galloped.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I spurred it all that I could.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'sdeath keep his hour, heaven help poor Citizens,
If Gentlemen grow thus wary: let him in.
Barren now, that hast in craft so fruitful been.
Your business sir to me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Do you not know me sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No in good truth sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: To know you I am bold sir,
You have lads of mine in mortgage, this is my day,
And here is your crowns.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Signior Innocentio;
My memory had quite lost you, pray sit both,
A bowl of wine here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sir it shall not need:
Please you to fetch my evidence, whilst we tell.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What needs this forward spring? faith two months hence
Had been to me as welcome.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sir I thank you.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Your hour draws on Signior Innocentio,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Go beat a drum in the garret, that no tongues
Of clocks be heard but mine.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Little past one.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Wind, wind.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thus windest thou to damnation.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: I will part with none sir, pardon me, till I see
Your writings: will you fetch the evidence sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What evidence sir, have I of yours?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My friend sir, whose money he lends me to redeem my mortgage.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Which you would have for your security.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: It is so sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No sir Innocentio,
sp.p:
Tomorrow on your bare word will I lend you thirty crowns
more: I love you sir, and wish you beware whose hands you
fall into: the world is a serpent.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: This does but spend the hour sir, will you take your money?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Let him see my writings then.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Have you such covenant from me? I remember none.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Your conscience is sufficient covenant sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ha! what is that conscience? I know no law-terms I,
Talk to me as to Citizen.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: We will dally no longer;
We knew what snake would sting us, and therefore brought
Our medicine against his venom: you will keep the writings,
And we will in the Court of conscience tender your crowns,
Whither this writ does summon you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A fox, and overtaken?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Serve writs upon me, yet keep my money too?
Dull slave hast thou no brain?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Brain! try this.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Will you as fits a Christian give us in
What is our right, and take your crowns sir yet?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: It is good to try men's patience, fetch me down
Those writing on my pillow, there they have slept
These two hours for you: must not friends jest? ha!

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Yes sir: let your men tell, just four hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Besides the use.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The use is there too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Hold: I will take it without telling, put it up.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Not till we see the writings.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Dare you touch it?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Dare! yea sir, and dare stab him to the heart,
Offers to take it from us:

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Who stabs first? Flings money amongst it.
Now touch it if you dare: there is gold of mine,
And if they lay one finger on it, cry thieves,
They come to rob me, touch it if you dare.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Damned wretch, thou wilt go quick to hell I fear.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No sir, the devil shall fetch me when I go.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That all my errand.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: We are cheated both.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Proceed, in your chancery suite, I have begun your bill.
Humbly complaining.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Of thee villain I will complain
That sells thy soul for money, devils on earth dwell,
And men are no where, all this world is hell.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I kiss thy forehead, my witty Oedipus
That canst unfold such riddles:

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Sir, I am bound
To do you all service, till I you all confound.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p:
Master Silver pen the proctor sir, sends word, if you
come not in tomorrow and personally depose your payment
of the two hndred crowns, you will be non-suited.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: That is a law-draught goes down coldly.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Why sir? It is but your swearing the money is paid.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
If oaths had back-doors to come in at, without danger
of damnation, to catch a man's soul by the back, swearing were brave.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: What answer shall I give the Proctors man?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Tell him my master shall come in and swear.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do, tell him: on thee I will build: now all my fear,
Is for appearance at the Chancellors Court.
No trick to save that?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I have a brave one for it.
Bring in a pottle of wine: will Carlo here my fellow,
Depose a truth if he see it, to help his master?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What thou not honest Carlo?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Here is the wine.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Set this to your head anon sir, when it is there
Away you, and tomorrow thou mayst swear
Before the Chancellor, and swear true, if he
Were in that case thou leftest him, it were in vain
To hope he could live, till thou camest back again.
All Knights at the Post learn this trick: the fit is upon me now.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p:
Take a good draught, it will help you sir: It gulps,
he is almost breathless Carolo; away.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am gon.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: He is gon, he is gon sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: One gulp more had choked me;
This wine had washed my fears off, thou hast given me power
To make me dote upon thee. Carolo is gon.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Yes and will swear his heart out, to your good.
Swear let him; be thyself and he damned too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So I may get by it. In my bosom sleep
(My dove, my love,) prosper but thou and I,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And let all else sink.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let them: so I kiss gold,
The young man's whore, the saint of him that is old.

div1.stage: Enter Prior, Alphege, Hillary, and Friers with pruning kniues, spades, &c. met by Subprior, and Shackle-soule.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Whither (mad-men) run you?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: To our Vines.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Your Vines?
(The tree of sin and shame?) this Serpent here,
Has with that liquorish poison, so set on fire
The brains of Nicodeme and Siluester,
That they in drunken rage have stabbed each other.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Stabbed!

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Yes, they bleed a little, but have no harm,
Their young blood with the grapes Juice being made (warm,
They brawled and struck, but I kept off the blows,
Yet the Sub Prior says from me their quarrel rose.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: It did.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: In very deed (for I not swear)
It did not sir: to me you malice bear,
As if that all such mischief done, were mine,
But cause yourself shall see how I repine
To see vice prosper, pardon me good Lord Prior,
If I a tell-tale be of what mine eyes
Beheld with water in them: sin will rise
In holy circles I see sometimes.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.l: What sin?

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: What hast thou seen?

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Would present I had not been,
But till I utter it, my clogged conscience bears
A man upon a woman.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I speak it in tears:
Scumbroth our cook, and a female I beheld
Kissing in our orchard: on her lips he dwelt
I think some half hour.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Shame to our reverend order!
A woman in our convent! Sin black as murder.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.l: Our cook shall be severely punished: a woman,
A tempter here.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Abominable!
Rush, thou wilt rebuke sin.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Though my Lord I am bad, I am not given that way.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.l: Let us some plagues invent to lay on this lecherous knave.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Some light punishment
(Good my Lord Prior) suppose it were your own fault,
Whip as you would be whipped, the best is nought.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: He shall be punished, and then loose his place.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: That sir shall be as we will: to our Vines: away.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: For shame give over, dare you profane this day
That is to holy uses consecrate?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Why? what day is this?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Lambert the martyr.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: No matter,
To vex thee deeper, this whole day we will spend,
Only about our Vines.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You vex not me,
But heaven: what warrants you to this?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Our will.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thou hast thy will, thy wish thou never shalt have,
In sight of heaven who sees and punishes
Men's black impieties; and in sight of these
(Sharers in thy full sin:) And in his sight,
To express whose vileness, there is no epithet.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: No matter what he says Rush.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I am known what I am.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: To thee I prophecy, (vicious old man to thee,
Who errest with lift-up-hands, and down-bowed knee,
Seemest to have had work in heaven: now (full of spite,
Only to eat a liquorish appetite;
Diggest our religious wales up, planting there
Luxurious fruits to pamper belly-cheer:
(For all thy pains to dress it,) of this Vine
Thy lustful lips shall never taste the wine.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Distracted fool, in stead of my just anger,
Thou only hast my pity: thou prophecy?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Laugh on, but since nor prayers prevail nor tears,
I will pour my grief into my Princes ears.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: He will go and complain to the King.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Let him complain,
Kings cannot Subjects of their food restrain,
Away.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Engender sin with sin; that wines rich heat
May bring forth Lust, Lust murder may beget,
But here strike sail, this bark awhile hale in,
And launch into the deep, a brighter sin:
Ho, Glitterbacke, ascend, to shackle-soule,
To shackle-soule ascend, ho Glitterbacke;
Thou richest spirit, thrust up thy golden head
From hell thus hie: when? art imprisoned
In misers chests so fast thou canst not come?
Or fearest thou the eves, or cut purses? here be some
Can save thee from their fingers: when? Arise;
And dazzle the approaching night with thy glistering eyes.

sp.speaker: Glitt:
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: How thou sweatest with coming? Save me those drops
(Golds pure Elixir) stilling from thy locks:
Shake from thy brows and hair that golden shower,
So: get home: quick: (to hell) least hell grow poor,
If Richmens paws once fasten thee, and beware
In the way thou meetest no Lawyers: they will pull thee bare,
Hence: down.

sp.speaker: Glitt.
sp.l: I am gon.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Cool night will call Friar Clement forth anon:
Angels, be you his strong temptation:
Wines lustful fires him warm not: At this spring,
(Scorned by the rest for him,) spread thy gilt wing,
Full in his eye; As he drinks water down
In streams of Avarice, let his weak soul drown.

div1.stage: Enter the King, Narcisco, Brisco, Spendola, Iouinelli, Rufman, followed by Astolfo.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I do beseech your Highness, yet turn back
And comfort the sad Lady, whose fair eyes
Are worn away with weeping.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: If her eyes be worn away, what should a man do
With a blind wife? kill her with flies?

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: I cannot abide a woman that is fond of me.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: I would love a woman but as I love a walnut, to crack
It, and peel it, eat the meat, and then throw away the
Shell.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Or as noble-men use their great horses, when they
Are past service: sell them to brewers and make them drayhorses:
So use a woman.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: So so.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: The Indians are warm without clothes, and a man
Is best at ease without a woman: or if your Highness must
needs have one, have factors to buy the fairest, dote not any,
But like the turk, regard none, yet keep many.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You hear the Juries verdict.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Whose foreman is the devil?
These counsel thee to thy destruction.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Destruction? why? the heaven can abide but one sun,
I hope we on earth may love many men's daughters:
Tell Erminhilda so: send her home to the duke her father:
And tell him too, because the disease of marriage
Brings the stone with it, I hate a woman; I love not
To be cut: enclosed grounds are too rank.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Best feeding on the Commons then.
Will you not marry this chaste Lady then?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: No sir, and will you now my reason have?
A woman's is an insatiate grave.
Wherein he is damned that lies buried.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: On, on, away.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Brave battles! fight you, but I will win the day.

div1.stage: Manet, Astolpho. Enter Octauio and Ermynhilda.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I heard the story, tell it not over again,
It were cruelty to wound men, being half slain.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: It is cruelty too much, and too much shame
That one of your high birth, youth, beauty, name,
And vertues shining bright, should hence be sent
(Like some offender into banishment)
Abused by a King, and his luxurious train,
Of parasites, knaves, and fools, (a kingdoms bane,)
For them, by him not card for; you came not so,
But as his bride, his Queen, and bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: And yet am neither, from my fathers court
Came I (being sued by Princes too) for this?
To see him, his subjects scorn, and myself his?
Once thought I that his love had been (as fate)
Unmovable; and is it now turned to hate?
Yes, yes, he is wavering as the running stream,
And far more idle than a mad-man's dream.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Send to the duke your father, let him enforce
Your plighted marriage.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Worse than a divorce
No: to his eyes since hateful I am grown,
I will leave his Court and him, and die unknown.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: All runs I see to ruin.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If he pursue,
These godless courses, best we leave him too,
That land to itself must a quick downfall bring,
Whose King has lost all, but the name of King.

div1.stage: Enter Subprior with an earthen pot, and a lanthorne; Scumbroath with him with a peice.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Get thee to bed thou foolish man and sleep.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
How? Sleep? No sir no, I am turned a tyrant and
cannot sleep:
sp.l: I stand sentinel perdu, and somebody dies if I sleep,
I am possessed with the devil and cannot sleep.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What devil possesses thee?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
The fencers devil, a fighting devil; Rush has committed
a murder upon my body, and his carcass shall answer
it; the cock of my revenge is up.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: Murder! what murder?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
He has taken away my good name, which is flat manslaughter,
and half hanged me, which is as much as murder,
he told the Lord Prior and you that I was kissing a wench: It is
a lie, I give him the lie, and he shall fight with me at single
pistol against my caliver, do I look like a worm-monger?
when have you seen a wencher thus hairy as I am: Rush
thou diest for this treason against my members concupiscentiality.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: Thou would not kill him, would thou?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
No, but I will make him know what it is to boil a cook
in his own grease.
I am scalding hot; I am charged with fury, I carry a heart-burning
within me. I kiss a whore? I shall have boys cry out
to me, now who kissed Marry? No Rush, Scumbroth shall give thee
sugar pellets to eat, I will not be danced upon.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Let me persuade thy peace of mind tonight,
Get thee to rest, if Rush have thee belied,
Rejoice, by wrongs to have thy patience tried.
He shall forgiveness ask thee.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Let me but have one blow at his head with my cleaver
In the kitchen, and I freely forgive him, or let me bounce at
him.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: These bloody thoughts will damn thee into hell.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Do you think so? what becomes of our roaring
boys then that stab healths one to another, do you think
they will be damned up too?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I think so, for I know it, dear son to prayer,
Two sins beset thee, murder, and despair,
I charge thee meet me at my cell anon,
To save thee will I spend my orison.
In name of heaven I charge thee to be gon.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p:
Well sir, the cold water of your counsel has laid the
heat of my fury: he had met with his match, but I will shoot
off my anger, I will be gon, and why? Look you, because the
moon is up and makes horns at one of us; As the nobleman's
coach is drawn by four horses, the knights by two,
and the cuckold by three, even so am I drawn away with none
at all. Vale, Bonos Noches: I am possessed still: It buzzes, here.
Vale.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Blessed star of light, stuck there to illuminate
This world darkened over with sin: thou watchest late,
To guide man's coming home, showing there by
Heavens care of us, seeing how we tread awry
We have two great lights for midnight and for noon,
Because black deeds at no time should be done.
All hail to thee (now my best guide) be given,
What needs I earths candle, having the lamp of heaven?
Now Benedicite? where am I?
O whether am I going? Which way came I?
Ah welladay, I come to fill my pot,
With water not with thee; thou art mis-begot.
Else wouldst thou not lie there; what Orphans blood
Hast thou sucked out, to make this golden flood?
None drink this well but I, how is it then
Thou thus way-layest me, (thief to the soul of man?)
Would some poor wretch (by loss of law undone)
Had thee: go do him good: me canst thou none.
My wholesome cup is poisoned, it flows over
With man's damnation (gold,) drink there no more

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Not taste what all men thirst for? old and so brave,
When money assaults, one combat more I will have.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: So, ho, ho, father, Sub Prior.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Who is there? what art thou callest me?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: One that feeds the hungry, the cook sir, Scumbroth.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Come hither, I have for thee a golden prize.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Ha ha: he will take it.
Villains and fools will have gold, ( though got from hell,)
But they who do so, (as thou shalt) pay for it well.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
But stay, father Sub Prior, before we go one step
farther, what do you think I have done since I went from
you?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: No hurt I hope, say hast thou?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Hurt? If I did hurt in that, how much harm do Almanac
makers, who lie coldly quivering at it all the year
long? I did do nothing but stand staring at the man in the
moon.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: And what good thoughts bred that within thee?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
This: I thought to myself, what a happy fellow that
man in the moon was, to see so many fools and knaves here
below, and yet never to be troubled with them, nor meddle
with them.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: He is happy that meddles not with this world indeed.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
If that man in the moon should write a prognostication,
O he should not need to tell astronomical lies to
fill his book, nor talk in gibberish no man understands, of
Quartiles, Aspects, Stations, Retrogradations, Peragrations, Centricall,
Eccentricall, Cosmicall, Aeronicall, and such Palquodicall,
Solar, Lunar, Lunaticall vaulting over the rails of heaven,
that no Christian dare look upon their tricks, for fear his
wit break his neck.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thou puttest into a Sea, thou canst not sound,
Ignorance still is foe to Arts profound.
Come hither man, come hither.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Arts profound, Arts make men as very asses as women
do, I have no Art, and yet I know this Moon that
shines tonight, sees more than you or I do, for all your spectacles.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: True, it is the eye of heaven.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Which of the eyes? it is but the left eye: and the Sun
is the right: and yet the left sometimes sees more than the
right, and the right as much as the left, there is paxonisme for
you father globicall paxonisme.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: I understand thee not.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
No, why here is the oyster opened, I say the Sun sees
much knavery in a year, and the Moon more in a quarter: the
Moon sees men carried by a quarrelling watch to prison, and
the Sun sees the constable and the bookkeeper share fees
the next morning.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: That is not well.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Yes, but they swear it is well: the Moon sees bastards
come bawling into the world, and the Sun sees them shifted
and shuffled in dossers, away to nurse, and that is the cause we
have so many dosser-heads: the Moon sees old curmudgeons
come reeling from Taverns with sipping of half pints
of Sack, and the Sun sees the same churls the next day, soberly
cutting any man's throat for a penny.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: Enough of this: come hither: look what here lies.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
What here lies: marry, father Sub Prior, the devil and
some Usurers money have been here at their lechery, and see
what goodly children they have begot: if you will I will keep
the bastards at nurse.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I am content that half this gold be thine,
(If it be asked for never, for it is not mine,)
So thou wilt promise the other half to give
To such as I appoint.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: By this gold I will lay it out bravely, as you appoint me.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Look not to prosper; if thou dealest amiss;
Good works are keys opening the gates of bliss,
That golden key, thou in that heap mayst find;
If with it thou relieve the lame, sick, blind and hungry

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: I will do it I protest.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: One half bestowed so, take thyself the rest.
So fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Farewell good father, -- fool: I will give the blind a
dog to lead them, the lame shall to the whipping-post, the sick
shall die in a cage, and the hungry leap at a crust: I feed
rogues, the pox shall: the world is changed: a beggar yesterday,
and full of gold today: an ass today, and a prowed
scab tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Glit:
sp.p: Stay: stand. --

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Stand: cannot a Gentleman grow rich, but he must
keep knaves about him?

sp.speaker: Gilt:
sp.p: That gold is none of thine.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
But all the craft in that great head of yours cannot
