get it out of my fingers. S'wounds who the devil art thou?

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: A spirit sent up from hell to make thee rich.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Thank hell for it: hell makes worse fool rich in a year.

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: That gold I laid there for thee.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
When do you lay again, that I may have more of
these eggs?

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: Spend those I charge thee first.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Yes, Head.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.p: And bravely I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
What need you be at such charges, I will do it: but
shall the poor be a penny the better for me, as the old fellow
charge me, yea, or no?

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: No. --

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: It is thine own Genius cries unto thee no.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
My Genius, I am a cook, my Genius then belike is
a scullion; but when this is spent, can my Genius tell me
whither I shall have more.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: More.

sp.speaker: Flit.
sp.p: More.
More.
More.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Because my Genius keeps company with a great
man, I will take all their words; and his bond.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.l: When thou hast spent all that: I charge thee come
To the black tree, that stands in Naples grove,
Climb boldly to the top, and keep fast hold,
For there I will rain on thee a shower of gold,
If what thou seest there, thou to any tell,
Devils shall tear thee.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p:
Ha, ha! down down bright spirit, thou would be
missed anon, hell mint stands idle.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.l: Loose not that fool.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Be gon.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.l: Have care to meet at next infernal court:
The day draws nigh. --

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I thank thee for this spirit.

div1.stage: Enter K. Rufman, Narcisso, Spendola, Brisco, Iouinelli.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p:
You that complain against Barteruile, (receiver of all
Our tribute-monies) speak your wrongs; nay you have deafened
our ears too much already, he does confess your crowns
(paid and received) but to give back your writings there is
no clause, If them you will win, fight it out by our laws.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I humbly thank your highness. A gracious doom.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: One day to try this plea, to hell thou wilt come.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: To the next, we have business of our own, to the next:
O Barteruile! for these two hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I paid them to that man.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Now afore the King
And his Lords here, thou liest: thou hast paid me none.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Your cholers sirrah too high.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Though my collar stand
So high, it scarce bears up this falling band.
Thou sayst thou wilt swear thou hast paid it: uds nails swear so,
And the foul fiend go with it: two hundred crowns?
I have lost as much at loggats: swear but to revel,
And spend it in hell, gallop thee and that to the devil.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Man wherefore dost not swear?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Reach me a book.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let me before I swear, on my notes look,
I will tell you the very day; pray hold my staff,
Till I draw out my false eyes.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Draw thy heart out if it would thou mayst well say thy false eyes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The day: August, 14.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: That is now, be damned, and so away.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: On this day (August, 14.) I swear I paid
Into these hands, two hundred crowns in gold.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: S'wounds nor in silver: by this book I had none.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: One of you two is perjuriously forsworn.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: He, he, as I am true Christian man.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: He swears,
To your own hands he paid them.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Else let that eye,
Which sees me play false, scourge my perjury
With fearful stripes.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: O justice I fallen down dead!
Would I had lost all, though I had been cozened,
Rather than thou thy soul.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: He bleeds at mouth.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: See his staff (beating the earth, for heaven loves truth
Is burst in shivers, and that gold he swore
Was paid to me, lies scattered on the floor.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: He comes again, the devil will not receive him.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Take him away, we will punish him for this crime.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Beg his office: you a Courtier?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: I have a suite to your highness.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What is it count Spendola?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Master, look up man,
In this black trance had thy soul flown away,
I had wrought hard and made a holiday.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Loose not a minute (pew-fellow) leave him not yet,
I have whales here too, lie playing in the net.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I will take this gold at venture, (sweet young King,)
For all this hell-hound owes me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Do, and be gone.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I am paid: the devils turned puritan I fear,
He hates ( methinks ) to hear his own child swear.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The office of this perjured Barteruile,
I frankly give away, dividing it
To the Count Spendola, and our worthy friend
Brave Bohor here; farm it to whom you please.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We thank your Highness.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Who bids most, he buys it.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: If to his life, the devil gives longer lease,
To build more work for hell; go see, and from him
Exact a strict account of what he owes us.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: That strict account I will take.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Show him no favour.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If now thou art a just King, keep thy word,
With thy poor subjects.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How now uncle? why

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: This is thy day to hear the poor man's cry:
And yonder is crying enough, at thy Court gates;
Five hundred white heads, and scarce ten good hats,
Yet haberdashers too, of all trades, some,
Crying out they are undone.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Undone, by whom?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Marry, look: by such as you are, who go gay,
Wear it out, book down more, set to their hands but never pay;
Never in dear years was there such complaining
Of poor starved servants, or (when plagues are reigning)
Mourn orphans so and widows, as those do
That owe these sorrowful papers.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Pray how can I
To their complainings add a remedy?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I will tell thee how: are any here in debt
To Merchants, Mercers, Tailors? let them jet
In their own satins, pay for what they have taken,
And these will go less brave, to other less complain.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha ha!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The mighty wrongs the weak, the rich the poor,
This man should have his own, could he grease more
His too-fat lawyer; that wretch for his coat does sue,
But his coat is gon, and his skin flayed off too,
If his purse be over-matched: these gross impure
And rank diseases, long unto thy cure,
Thy word is in pawn for it, these are the poor's cries,
How wilt thou stop their throats?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: With halters.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Hang them.

sp.speaker: Ost.
sp.l: Hang them! any halters here list so set down?
This law-book speaks not so, yet it is thine own.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Still braving me with this? burn it.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Yes do.
If you burn all the week, burn saturday too:
Do one good days-deed first, read poor men's plaints.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hells plagues confound them: in their heads and thine
Vex me no more.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I warrant thee I will save mine.
Holy Saint pardon me, (alas good father, my brain
So wild is I forgot thee, but I will to him again,
sp.p:
It is but an old man's head off. King take it, I will speak whilst
this stands on my shoulders.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But that you are. --

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: An honest man, thou woulds have this, O I beseek
Thy attention to this Reverend sub-Prior,
Who plains against disorders of this House;
Where once Devotion dwelt and Charity,
There is Drunkenness now, Gluttony, and Lechery,
Tell thou the Tale.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Bad Story soon is told;
Because it is foul, that Leaf does all enfold,
Their sins grow high, and fearful, and strike at Heaven,
Punish them thou, whose power from thence is given.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Your Friars so lusty!

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: All the Barbers in Naples tell news of that Priory.

sp.speaker: Bris:
sp.p:
I would your Grace would let me purge this house of
her infection; bestow the Livings of it on me, I will sweeten
it in one Month.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: He will lay it in Lavender.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The Convent, the Demesnes, Immunities,
Rents, Customs, Chartres, what to this house of Baall
soever is belonging -- Brisco it is thine.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.p:
Would  rob the Church too, (Now 
thou hast  nothing lest 
 scarce for  thyself?
)

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: O heaven for-fend such theft!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Bestow it at thy pleasure.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Woe to those days,
When to raise Upstarts, the poor CHURCH decays.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Call back thy gift ( O King) and ere these eyes
Behold unhallowed hands to Tyrannize
Where many a good man has his Orisons said,
And many a Requiem been sung out for the Dead,
(Till I am thrust out by Death,) O let me have
My dwelling there, there let me dig my Grave,
With mine own Nails, (shut up from worldly Light,
Between two walls,) and die an Anchorite.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: I refer you to your Patron there.

sp.speaker: Bris:
sp.l: That is I:
Show me first where your Abbey-gold sleeps, then go die.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: I fear RELIGIONS Fall: Alacke I see
This world is a City built by the most Hie,
But kept by man, (GODS) greatest enemy.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Let ill-news fly together, thou art full of tears,
But I more full of woes, of cares, of fears.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'sdeath shall we have yet fair weather?

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Here is one storm more.

sp.speaker: Ast:
sp.l: Calabrias Duke demands of you a Daughter:

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Let me but lie with his wife, I will give him a Son.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: He sends for Erminghild.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Deliver her.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: She is not to be found.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Ye are an old Fool,
To ask for that which is not.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Thus he says,
Deny her and look for wars.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: So go your ways.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I am quickly gone.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: With Sack I will swear you are,
This was short and sweet, -- Seems then we shall have wars,
Bohor, the Drum must scold, the Canon thunder:
Fighting about a wench.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Tush, that is no wonder,

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Who bailed him out of Hell? damned perjured caitiff!
Out of mine eye.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: I never begged before,
Pardon his crime (I entreat) and back restore
Both your high favour to him, and his place.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let me want life, rather than want your Grace.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Do you think I will loose the Kings gift?

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: I will send you Gold.

sp.speaker: Spen:
sp.l: That stops my mouth, pray let him still Sir hold,
This Office of Receiver, I resign
That part which I have in it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: And I all mine.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Sirrah, thank these Lords.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: I shall their loves deserve.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p:
Barteruile, we have wars, I will have thee lend me
some thirty thousand Chicquines at least.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Take all my Gold.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Well, get you home with your bags sir, we will make bold.

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: Your Majesty shall have what bags you will,
Bags only, but I will keep my money still.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Now Shalcan, some new Spirit.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: A thousand wenches
Stark-naked, to play at Leap-frog.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: O rare sight!

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: Your uncle,

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'sdeath, still haunted with this gray sprite.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: You need no Tailors now, but Armourers,
There is a dear reckoning for you all to pay,
About a Lady; the Calabrian Duke
Is on a March: the Lightning flashes now,
You will hear the crack anon. Before the star
To call whom up, the wakeful Cock doth sing
Be twice more seen abroad; At your City gates
The Devils pursuivant will beat (the Canon)
Will these brisk leaders (stuck with Ostrich-feathers.)
Go brave your enemy now, and beat him back?
Save thee, thy Kingdom, and themselves from wrack?

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Dotard, I scorn to take prescription
From any breath to which ours is supreme,
Stood Devils with fire-works on your battlements,
A thousand Armed Ioues at your proud walls
Hurling forked Thunder, and the gates rammed up
With piles of Citizens heads, our spring-tide pleasures
No adverse winds, no Torrent shall resist!
Midst flames we will dance, and die a Nerenist.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Fight you, ye are good for nothing else.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: They mock us.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: All stark mad: let us be wise,
And fly from buildings falling to the surer side,
If we can his safety, if not, (our own provide.)

div1.stage: Enter Barteruile like a Turke; -- Lurchall.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou hadst like thou had sent me swearing into Hell,
I will weave my Nets myself, how dost thou like me?
Is not this habit Turke-Merchant-like?

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: A mere Turk sir, none can take you for less.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: King borrow thirty thousand Chequines of me! ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: But pray sir, what is it turns you into a Turk?

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: That, for which many their Religion,
Most men their Faith, all change their honesty,
Profit, (that gilded god) Commodity.
He that would grow damned-Rich, yet live secure,
Must keep a case of Faces, sometimes demure.
Sometimes a grum-surly sir, now play the Jew,
Then the Precisian; Not a man we will view.
But varies so. Myself, (of bashful nature)
Am thus supplied by Art.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mine own dear creature.
But sir, your Aims, and ends in this.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Marry these --
A hundred thousand-Florins fill my Coffers,
Some of it is mine own, and some the Kings,
Some taken up at use of sundry Merchants,
To pay at six six months, on mine own band,)
Sue that, I will keep the monies in my hand.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You will break sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Not mine own neck, but their backs;
To get their monies, Bartaruile must die,
Make will, name an executor, which am I.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Rare!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Given out his kinsman, lately employed
him in Turky.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What will hence befall?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Like an executor will I cozen all.
Make creditors Orphans, and widows spend those tears
They saved from their late husbands burials;
They get not twopence in the pound.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: They will tell the King.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The King? ha ha: the King is going this way;
He means to borrow,
(If the wars holds) my gold: yes: when tomorrow.
All debts of mine, on him shall be conferred,
I have briefs and tickets which from time to time
Show what large sums his minions have fetched from me,
His tribute money has paid it, that is no matter,
The world bites these dead, whom alive they flatter.
And so must I; then give it out I left
A complete state, but the Kings death bereft
Me of those sums he owed.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Say the King prevails.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: With that wind must I likewise shift my sail:
And where the fox gets nothing, will turn Ape,
Make legs, crouch, kiss my paw, present some stale
Device of vertues triumph to express
How much I joy him safe, wish nothing less.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: But how can you excuse your turning Turk?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Easiest of all: I will swear, this saved my life,
Pursued by kennels of barking creditors:
For my much love to him, and thus being forced
To walk obscure, my credit fell to wrack,
Want of return made all my factors break,
In parts remote; to recompense which loss,
And that with safety I may give direction
To my disturbed state, crave I the Kings protection.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Protection! what is that?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A merchant, and yet knowest not
What a protection is? I will tell thee.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Pray sir, for I never broke with any man.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: It is a buckler of a large fair compass
Quilted within with Fox-skins: in the midst
A pike sticks out, (sometimes of two years long,
And sometimes longer.) And this pike keeps off
Sergeants and Bailiffs, Actions, and Arrests:
It is a strong charm against all the noisome smells
Of Counters, Jailers, garnishes, and such hells;
By this, a debtor crazed, so lusty grows,
He may walk by, and play with his creditors nose.
Under this buckler, here I will lie and fence.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You have out-reached me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I will out-reach the devil:
But I tempt danger: go thou and fetch some Friar
As if (at point of death,) I did desire,
(No, Barteruile did desire (to make confession:
If any creditors beat, or rail at door,
Upstarts this Turk and answers them.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Why fetch I a Friar?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have a reaching plot in that (boy) hasten,
That we may smile in our securer port:
Seeing others sea-tossed: why it is but a sport
For him that is safe, to see the proud waves swallow
Whole fleets of wretched souls: it needs must follow,
Nature sent man into the world, (alone,)
Without all company, but to care for one, and that I will do.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: True City doctrine sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Away, thy haste, our richest love shall earn,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I came to teach, but now ( methinks ) must learn.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
What says the prodigal child in the painted cloth?
when all his money was spent and gon, they turned him out
unnecessary; then did he weep and wist not what to do,
for he was in his hose and doublet verily; the best is, there are
but two batches of people moulded in this world, that is to say
Gentlemen and Beggars; or Beggars and Gentlemen, or
Gentlemanlike Beggars, or Beggar-like Gentle-men; I rank
with one of these I am sure, tag and rag one with another: Am
I one of those whom Fortune favours? No no, if Fortune favoured
me, I should be full, but Fortune favours nobody but
Garlic, nor Garlic neither now, yet she has strong reason
to love it; for though Garlic made her smell abominably in
the nostrils of the gallants, yet she had smelt and stunk
worse but for garlic: One filthy sent takes away another.
She once smiled upon me like a lamb, when she gave me
gold, but now she roars upon me like a Lion. Stay: what
said head? Spend this bravely, and thou shalt have more:
can any prodigal new-come upstart spend it more bravely?
and now to get more, I must go into the grove of Naples
that is here, and get into a black tree, here is a black tree too,
but art thou he?

sp.speaker: Glitt.
sp.p: He

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Ha ha, where art thou my sweet great head?

sp.speaker: Glitt.
sp.p: Head.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
O at the head, that is to say at the top: how shall I get
up? for it is hard when a man is down in this world to get up,
I shall never climb hie.

sp.speaker: Glitt.
sp.p: Hie.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: I will hie me then, but I am as heavy as a sow of lead.

sp.speaker: Giltt:
sp.p: Lead.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Yes, I will lead (big Head) whatsoever follows,
Many a gallant for gold, has climbed higher on a gallows.
sp.p:
The storm even as Head nodded) is coming: Cook, lick
thy fingers, now or never.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.p: Now or never.

div1.stage: Rayne, Thunder and lightning: Enter Lucifer and Devils.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Oooh.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: This is the tree.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
On which would you all were hanged, so I were off it,
and safe at home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And this (I am sure it is this) the horrid grove
Where witches broods engender, (our place of meeting.)

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Do witches engender here: s'wounds I shall be the
devils bawd whilst he goes to his lechery.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And this the hideous black infernal hour:
Has no appearance yet? if their least minute
Our vassals break, sink shall these trees to hell.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This grove I will turn into a brimstone lake
Which shall be ever-burning.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
The best is, if I be a match in the devils tinderbox, I
can stink no worse than I do already.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Not yet come? Oooh!

div1.stage: Enter Shacklesoule, Rufman, embrace, and Lurchall, at seuerall dores with other diuels.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Oooh, oooh.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Sure these are no Christian
Devils, they so love one another.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Stand forth.

div1.stage: Sits vnder the tree all about him.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Friar Rush amongst them!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And here unlade you of that precious freight
For which you went, (men's souls;) what voyage is made?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: No saving voyage, but a damning.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
I thought the devil was turned Merchant, there is so
many Pirates at Sea.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: In the Court of Naples have I prospered well,
And brave souls shall I shortly ship to hell
In sensual streams, Courtier and King I have crowned,
From whence war is flowing, whose tide shall all confound.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Are there gentlemen devils too? this is one of those,
Who studies the black Art, that is to say, drinks Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Are all then good in the City?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No Lucifer.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: No nor scarce in the suburbs.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Great Prince of devils,
Thy hests I have obeyed,
I am bartering for one soul, able to lade
An Argosy; if City-oaths, if perjuries,
Cheatings, or gnawing men's souls by usuries,
If all the villainies (that a City can,)
Are able to get thee a son, I have found that man.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Serve him up, --

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Alas, now now.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Damnation gives his soul but one turn more,
Cause he shall be enough.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
It is no marvel if markets be dear, when the City
is bound to find the devil roast-meat.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Has Rush lain idle?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Idle? no Lucifer.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: All the world is turned devil. Rush is one too,

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Idle? I have your nimblest devil been,
In twenty shapes begetting sin.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: One was to get me thrust out of the priory.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I am fishing for a whole school of Friars.
All are gluttoning or muttoning, stabbing or swelling
There is only one Lamb scapes my killing,
But I will have him: then there is a cook. --

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Whose arse makes buttons.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Of whom I some revenge have took.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: The devil choake you for it.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: He mickle scathe has done me,
And the knave thinks to out-run me.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Not too fast.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Kick his guilty soul hither.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I will drive him to despair,
And make him hang himself.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: For hanging I stand fair.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.l: Go, ply your works, our Sessions are at hand.

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.l: We fly to execute thy dread command.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Would I could fly into a bench-hole!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But what have you done? nothing.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: We have all like bees
Wrought in that Hive of soul (the busy world:)
Some have lain in cheesemongers shops, paring leaden waits.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Would I were there but with a paring of cheese.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: For one half ounce, we had a chandlers soul

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: If he melted tallow, he smelt sweetly as I do.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: Walk round hells shambles, thou shalt see there sticks
Some four butchers souls, puffed quaintly up with pricks.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: 4. Sweet-breads I hold my life, that devil is an ass,

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: Tailors over-reachers, for to this it is grown,
They scorn thy hell, having better of their own.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: They fear not satin nor all his works.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: I have with this fist beat upon rich-mens hearts,
To make them harder: and these two thumbs thrust,
(In open Churches) into brave dames ears.
Damning up attention; whilst the loose eye peers
For fashions of gowning, laces, pearls, ruffs,
Falls, calls, tires, wires, caps, hats, and muffs, and puffs.
For so the face be smug, and carcass gay,
That is all their pride.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It will be a festival day
When those sweet Ducks comes to us: loose them not: go:
More souls you pay to hell, the less you owe.
This Ewe-tree blast with your hot-scorching breath,
A mark, ( to the witch who next sits here) of death.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ooooh. --

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Call you this, raining down of gold? I am wet to the
skin in the shower, but it is with sweating for fear: had I,
now had the conscience that some Vintners and Inholders
have? here might I have gotten the devil and all. But two
sins have undone me, prodigality, and covetousness: and
three Pees have peppered me, the Punk, the Pot, and Pipe of
smoke, out of my pocket my gold did soak. I cannot swear
now, s'wounds I am gallant: but I can swear as many of the
ragged Regiment do, s'wounds I have been a gallant. But I am
now down, dejected, and debashed, and can better draw out
a thirdendale gallant, that is to say, a gallant that wants of his
true measure, than any tapster can draw him out of his scores:
thus he sets up, and thus he is pulls down, thus is he raised,
and thus declined:
sp.l: Singulariter,
Nominatiuo, Hic Gallantus, a Gallant.
Genetiuo, Hugipus, brave.
Datiuo Huic, If he gets once a lick,
Accusatiuo Hunc, Of a taffeta Punk.
Accusatiuo Hanc, His cheeks will grow sank,
Hunc, Hanc, and Hoc, With lifting up her smock.
Vocatiuo, O ! He is gon if he cries so.
Ablatiuo, ab hoc Away with him, he has the pock
Pluraliter, Nominatiuo, Hi gallanti, If the pox he can defy,
Genetiuo, Horum, Yet he is a beggar in coram.
Datiuo, His: His gilt rapier he does miss.
Accusatiuo Hos, Without his cloak he goes.
Accusatiuo Has, To the Counter he must pass.
Hos, has. et Hæc, With two Catchpoles at his back.
Vocatiuo, O! A hole he desired, and to the hole he must go.
Ablatiuo, ab His, Thus many a Gallant declined is.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Daughter to the Calabriam Duke.
The hapless troth-plight wife to your sad King.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Alack! what notes are these I hear you sing?
Pardon me madam:
O Lady! want of you has bred much woe;
Calamity does everywhere overflow,
All long of your strange absence.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I confess,
Laden with your Kings contempt, and loath to bear
Shame to my country, who from thence came freighted
With many glorious honours, I preferred
An obscure life before a public shame;
O then (good father) be it not my blame
If my supposed death, on the King have thrown,
Dangers, which from himself are merely grown.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What (princely Maiden) would you wish me do?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I do conjure you sir, by all the bonds
Tie you to pious Acts, you would make way
To my incensed father; give him these lines,
This Ring, pledge of that blessing he delivered me
At our last parting: add unto these, if ever
His daughters memory to him were dear,
To wound the Prince let his rash hand forbear:
Since through each wound he gives him, I am slain,
If the sad king you meet, venture to tell him
That more for him, than he for me, I bide,
And am his subject still, though not his bride.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: This shall I do, how shall we meet again?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Fears follow me so, I know not where nor when.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Hark how the sound of horror beats the Air,
Your fathers up in Arms and does prepare
Sharpe vengeance, for this city, woe is me: trust you
To me, who never made much of woman yet,
Rest here sweet maid, till an old Friar beget
What joys he can to comfort thee? Is Clement grown
A woman's man now? No, I am not mine own,
Where your command may sway me:
Much more in this,
Where heaven) through vertues trial) makes you his.

div1.stage: A table is set out with a candle burning, a deaths head, a cloke and a crosse; Sub Prior sits reading:
Enter Shackle-soule, leading in an Italian Zany, fiue or 6. Gurtizans, euery one holding a Iewell.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: that is he, and there is your golden hire to charm him;
Your fees I will treble, let but lusts flame be felt;
The Alpine-snow at the sun's beams does melt,
So let your beauties thaw his frozen Age,
First to act an old Lecher, then a devil on hells black stage:
Strike, strike your silver strings: brave set of whores?
At your striking up, devils dance, and all hell roars.

div1.stage: Zany and Curtizans fall into a short dance,

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What sound offends mine ear? Soul of temptation?
Enchanters I defy ye, get you gon;
I am blind to your enticements, from this I learn,
At how dear rate the careless world does earn.
That thing called pleasure: how many souls do fall?
(Sold for a little guilt to daub this wall?)
Hence with your witchcrafts, the sight of this drives hence,
All thoughts besieging our voluptuous sense.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Another bait, at this he will not bite.

div1.stage: The Zany singes: Sub Prior holds his head downe as fast a sleepe.

sp.speaker: Zany.
sp.l: Will you have a dainty girl? here it is:
Coral lips, teeth of pearl: here it is:
Cherry cheeks, softest flesh; that is she,
Breath like May, sweet and fresh; she she.
Be she white; black, or brown,
Pleasure your bed shall crown,
Chose her then, use her then,
Women are made for men.
Pretty, pretty wast:
Sweet to be embraced:
Pretty leg, O pretty foot,
To beauties tree the root,
This is she shall do it,
Or she shall do it, or she shall do it, she shall do it, she shall do it
Kiss, kiss, play, play, come and dally,
Tumble, tumble, tumble, in beauties valley.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: His soul is chained in pleasures, bind it fast,
If he break your charms, the strongest spell comes last.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Hence devils incarnate, it is not the sorcery
Of your deceitful tunes, shuts up mine eye,
Mine ears are likewise stopped, hence, hence I say.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha ha, a man of ye, a clod of clay.

div1.stage: Enter Shacklesoule, or some spirit in a frightfull shape.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Are all thy incantations spent now? art come again?
Base workmanship of heaven, what other train,
Were all hells frightful horrors stuck in thy look,
Thou canst not shake me.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I can.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thou liest, thou shalt not.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I bring thee tidings of thy death this night.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: How dost thou know that hour of my last fight?
False herald, Minister of despair and lies.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I know to how many minutes thy days must rise.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Who gives thee the number.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: All things to us are known,
Whatever have been, are, or shall be done.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I will pose thee presently, what is this thou fiend
Which now I have turned too, do but tell me that
And I will believe thee.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I scorn to be thy slave:

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: down, down, and sink into thy damned cave:
Look here, dost fly thou hell-hound? I dare thee stand,
Over thee by these holy spells have I strong command,
Thy batteries are too weak: by goodmen's prayers,
The continence of saints, (by which as stayres,
They ascend to heaven) by Virgins chastity;
By Martyrs crowned deaths, which recorded lie
In silver leaves, above: I charge thee down,
Howl where thou art bound in slavery, till the last doom,

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Storms, thunder, lightning, rip up the earths womb.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Eternal power, thanks on my humbled knee,
Thou still to constant breasts givest victory.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: No way to conquer thee? I will give thee over:
Never fished I so, (yet lost a soul) before.

div1.stage: Allarums. Enter King, Rufman, Spendola, Brisco, with drawne weapons. Iouinelli here.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p:
Black horrors, mischief ruin and confusion
affright us, follow us.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Dare them to the face,
And you fright them.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: No safety but to fly.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Whither Spendola, whither? better stay, and die.

div1.stage: Enter Narcisco: King, Allarums afar of.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: What hope? what news?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Is my uncle fled?

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: He is gon: -- And fights against you.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Follow him damnation,
That leaves his Prince so in distress, in misery;
O bane of Kings! (thou enchanting flattery,)
Thy venom now I feele, eating my heart,
More mortal than an Indians poisoned dart.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Ye are too dejected, gather head and fight it out.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The head is here, where are hands to lay about?

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Where is the King?

sp.speaker: Kir.
sp.l: The man that title mocks
Is here, (thou sad-visage man) are any hired to kill me,
Or betray me? let them come:
Griefs growing extreme, death is a gentle doom.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Prepare then for the worst.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I am armed for it: show it.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Thy kingdom is a weak ship, bruised, split, sinking,
Nor hast thou any pilot to waft us over
Out of this foul Sea, to some calmer shore.
Thy peoples hearts are turned to rocks of flint,
The Scholar, Soldier, and the Mariner,
Whom (as themselves say) once thou troddest upon,
Now serve as wheels of thy destruction.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Flying swiftly backward, the kingly Lions quailed,
What shall the weaker herds do, if he fall?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Let us fly.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: S'wounds whither?

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: So we may be safe --

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: But where?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: At Barteruile: the churl is to me beholden,
His house so stands, we may enter without fear.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Be it so, to Barteruile.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: What will your Highness do?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Die Spendola, a miserable King,
None here can hinder us of that.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: How? die? -- have you any stomach to death sirs?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Nor I.
Troth is, though you grow desperate, we will grow wise.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Farewell sir, we will save one.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O my cruellest enemies!
Stabs Brutus at me too?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Now mine own or never.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why art not thou gon?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: I, I will stick to you ever:
I am no Courtier sir of fortunes making

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou art no wise man to prefer thy love.
To me, before thy life, pray thee leave me.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I shall not hate the world so really
As else I would, O had the ancient race
Of men (who had long leases of their lives)
Been wretched as we are, no recompense
Could the Gods have given them for their being here,
But now more pitiful wise nature grows,
Who cuts off man's years to cut off his woes.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: True sir, and teaches him a thousand ways
To lead him out this horrid giddy maze.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I apprehend thee, a small daggers point,
Opens the veins to cure our pleurisy.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Than to be made your foes-slave, better die.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A hundred-thousand deaths, than like a captive
Be chained to grace proud Caesar's Chariot wheel.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Much less a petty Dukes.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Fetch me dear friend,
An armed Pistol, and mouth it at my breast:
I will make away myself, and all my sorrows
Are made away.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: The best and nobler spirits
Have done the like.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Your bravest men at Arms
have done the like.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Philosophers have done it.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Great peers have done it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Kings have done the like.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And I will do it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Nay it shall never be said,
I lived a minute after you: here, here.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I embrace thee noblest friend.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Let us sail together.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Content brave Bohor: O! but whither? whither?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: From hell, (this world,) from fiends, (in shapes of men.)

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: No: into hell, from men to be damned black with fiends.
Methinks I see hell jaws to swallow us.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Fuh, this is but the swimming of your brain,
By looking downwards with a timorous eye.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: My soul was sunk too low, to look more high,
Forgiveness heaven. --

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: The whips of furies lash me: the foe comes on.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And we will meet him, dare confusion,
And the worlds mixed poisons, there is a hand
That fights for Kings, and under that we will stand.

div1.stage: Allarum still a farre off: Enter a Frier running.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Whither runs this Friar?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: To save my wretched life,
From the insolent soldier, threatening the Cities spoil.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Of what house art thou?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Of father Clements Order,
sp.p:
The Capachines Sub Prior: a quick messenger fetched me to
be rich Bateruiles confessor, who lies adying.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: He does, but I
Have come thus far, with so much jeopardy.
That could I safely get the keys shore,
Nor the priory would I see more.
For charities sake, direct me, and defend me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: To help distressed men, religion binds me,
Shouldst thou in this hot broils, be met abroad,
It will be judged you leave your Priory,
Carrying gold and silver with you.

sp.speaker: Eri.
sp.l: Alas I have none.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But Friar if you be thus taken, your life is gon,
Here, here, cast off thy habit, better that lie
In the Streets than thou poor wretch; wear mine, and away
Strike down that lane.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Thanks master, for your lives I will pray.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This Bohor shall disguise me, whither wilt thou fly?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: I will shift I warrant: hast thou to the Priory,

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: If we never meet again, (best friend) farewell.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Not meet, yes, I hope, you must not thus cheat hell.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I will not trust this fellow: to the Priory, no:
Barteruiles Confessor: if to betray
Thou findest the churl apt, leave him, if not, there stay,
The downfall of that Prince, is quick and steep.
Who has no heart to leave, nor power to keep,

div1.stage: Enter Barteruile and Lurchall, with the Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Make the door sure the house is round beset.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Beset!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Put up: fear nothing: Armies should they enter,
Cannot here find you.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How shall we escape?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Send for your trunks and jewels, I will ship you this
night mean time, this unknown way, leads to a cellar,
where a world cannot fetch you forth: In, In, if danger pursue
you, in a dry-fat I will pack you hence.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: S'wounds into the dungeon?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So to Sardini:
Your cloaks and your gilt rapiers, down, down, down.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How soon meets Babels-pride, confusion?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What nest of birds are these new-killed with fear?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Fowl cannot last long sweet, therefore kept there Sergeants.
In my cold cellar; stay, house beset? what fees?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Such as strike dead the heart, yet give no blows.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This -- footra for them: proclamations Lurchall,
six thousand Crowns are his, can these betray,
Soon earned, we will share fetch, the Calabriam hither,
They are here say: damn them.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You shall de damned together.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Where is that devote sick man desires to take
Leave off this world? Deus hic to all now here.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now Domine Friar; what I to you confess.
You are bound by oath to keep.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I aver no less.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Keep then this close, I am no Turk, not I,
But Barteruile disguised in policy.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Are you the Sick man?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Sick of a disease,
Bad as a plague to Citizens, I must break,
Play a bankrupts part) I have money of the kings,
Of merchants, I will keep all, these are City-springs;
Here lies Sergeants Leaguer: about my doors:
My house to me is an hospital, they the sores
Which run upon me vilely, (peep I but out.)
To raise this Dunkirke siege, thus cast I about.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Let us hear, pray how?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thus, thus sweet Domine Friar,
I will be like you, a Capuchin: So, by your Prior,
Sub-prior, and Convent, I may be fetched hence,
Spite of all Shoulder-clappers violence.
Though the King should lay hands on me, I would not tarry.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You need not.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You are my guard, my Sanctuary.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But what your level in this, when this is done?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Alas! what level but pure devotion?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The Devil you have.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: When I die there, take All:
Will you go to your prior and tell this?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Yes I shall.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I will send him an earnest penny (a hundred Crowns)
As the first stone my charity builds upon.
What drum is this? come, dispatch Friar, and be gon.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Out of this hell thou meanest: yes I will fly from thee
As from the Devils hangman: thou wilt else betray me.
World! to what crest of villainy art thou grown?
When (of good men) whole kingdoms scarce breed One.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p:
Here is the Duke of Calabria sir if you have made me
tell a lie, they will send me of a voyage to the island of Hogs and
Devils, (the Barmudas,) the Duke sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: His grace is welcome, alas! I had more need
To have Physicians and Apothecaries,
Than fighters at my gates: Lurchall why come they?

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.l: Deliver up those monsters in thy house,
That have devoured a Kingdom and the King.
It is death to thee, and him, if thou detainest them.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I detain them, here, here, here.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Reward if thou deliverest them.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
I am past rewarding in this world, I look
only for good men's prayers, there is the key Lurchall.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Unbind him: stay why did thy house receive them?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Full sore against my will: the bed I rise from
Count I my death-bed; for (each minute) I look
When Angels (heavens good porters) will let me in,
Yet (like my betters) I am heavy laden with sin.
sp.p:
And being thus sick, and at last gasp, I sent for my
nearest cozen, my executor,
sp.l: Who seeing brave fellows beating at my gates,
Took them for honest men, let them in simply,
And undertook this night, to have shipped them hence;
My faithful Servant telling me this, (In zeal,
To you and my country) I bid him, All reveal.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thou hast played a Subjects part in it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He will lead you to them.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My Lord, take force and seize them, never stand upon
More trials; give them speedy execution.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Come fellow.--

div1.stage: Exeunt Ast: and Lurchall cum Militibus.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Your grace has done with me?

sp.speaker: Calab.
sp.l: Go, look to thy health:
The crowns the proclamation promised,
Shall to thy man be paid.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thanks to your Grace:
Alas what I did in this, was for no hire.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ha ha, the rent of a cellar never was so dear.

div1.stage: As they goe off; Enter Octauio with Rufman and a guard.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Are the rest taken?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The grand-Pirate is here.
Here is the Devils bellows, kindled all those fires,
Which now are burning: This is the Snake, whose sting
(being kept warm in the bosom of a King)
Struck him to the heart This he, who by the force
Of his damned Arguments, was the first divorce,
Of the Kings Love, this is Bohor.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: This that Serpent,
Ye have all (like Traitors) wrought a Princes fall,
And all shall taste one death.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Sirrah, where is the King?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: Warrant me life, I will bring you to the place
where you shall take him.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Wilt thou betray him Slave?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Thou shalt have life.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: And you the King shall have.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: And the Gallows shall have thee, else hang me. Away

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.l: Alas, where is the sub Prior?

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Here; what ailest thou?

sp.speaker: Scu:
sp.l: Can you pick nothing out of my face?
Is there not a Deaths-head standing on my shoulders?

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Why, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Scu:
sp.l: The Lord Prior is called away:

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Whither, by whom?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: By the Great-head, I think he cozened me,
He is gone to the black-squibb-tree, to
Iudas Oak, set by the Devil, I told you then,
I saw Friar Rush spit fire amongst other Hell-cats,
and ye would not believe me. Now I tell you,
that the Prior is choked; will his choking
go down your throat?

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: How choked?

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.p:
Yes, choked: that of which men die overnight, and
are well the next morning, wine has killed the Lord Prior:
he would in a bravery taste the liquor of our Vines, because
you threatened he should never lick his lips after. And the
Kernel of a grape stopped his windpipe, for want of a scouring-stick.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Art thou sure he is dead?

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.l: How dead, because I would be sure,
I cut his throat of purpose, to take out the
Kernel.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Most fearful and prodigious, whither runnest thou?

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.p:
To see more throats cut, and Execution of certain
Gallants is this morning. And I came running to see them,
Who like a whore spoils every good thing that comes into
his hand. The hang-man, I leave you to the Gallows.

div1.stage: Enter Barteruile like a Frier, brought in by the Subprior, the King, Shackle-soule, and Lurchall, with others.

sp.speaker: Rush:
sp.l: Welcome dear brother: now your heed must be
Not to look back at this worlds vanity,
Riches and pleasures: you have laid aside
That Garment, and must now be mortified.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: I am mortified, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: So is the Devil.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Your Gold and silver, you must see no more.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: O Fie! give it every farthing to the poor,
When I have sent for it hither.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That will be never.

sp.speaker: Rush:
sp.l: Your money shall be spent in pious sort.

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: I know that: Let my sense be the better for it,
That is all I crave for, after I am dead.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.l: Many a Requiem for it shall be said.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: What Drum is this?

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.l: Fryers stand upon your Guard.
The Priory is beset with Armed-men,
Of which some Troupes are entered.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I am betrayed.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Lurchall I feele my weasand pipe cut.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I warrant you.

div1.stage: Enter Calabria, Octauio, Astolfo, Rufman led by two holding pistalls, Souldiers, drums, and Cullors.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Guard the Abbey gates, let not a Friar go forth:
You have a King amongst you, which is he?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A King!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I know of none here.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Villains you lie:

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: This caitiff does delude you, torture him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hang him, and these up over the Abbey walls,
Our wrath shall smite like thunder where it falls.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I shall like a dog, die without money, Lurchall.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Tyrant, that royal heart thou huntest, is here,
Stand from me all, you have betrayed me all,
And I will trust none of you, if the Lion must fall,
Fall shall he like a Lion; thinkst thou (base Lord)
Because the glorious Sun behind black clouds
Has a while hid his beams, he is darkened for ever?
Eclipsed never more to shine, yes, and to throw
Fires from his sparklings eyes, thee to confound,
Touch not that noble friend of mine, (It seems,
For my sake marked for danger,) let your arrows
(Dipped in rank poison) be shot all at me,
Since all is lost, die nobly, and loose life too:
O uncle! must the first dart fly from you?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Into thy bosom fly I.

sp.speaker: Kin
sp.l: To betray me?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: To fight for thee till I can fight no more:
Hadst thou possessed this Kingly spirit before,
We never had left thee: what makes Iudas here?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Here is he that to the Duke thy life betrayed.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Bohor!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Aye, Bohor.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: I told him where you were.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I tell thee thou art a traitor and I will have
Thy head off, or thou mine.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Head?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Thou art a slave?
Thou seest Duke what to trust too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have confessed, and shall be hanged, the King?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Our fair game come to this? Our swords I see:
Must from your hearts-blood let out all my wrongs,
A murdered daughter for just vengeance cries,
Whom to appease, your lives we will sacrifice:
Beat the drom.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thunder mock thunder, beat ours.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O let these fires be quenched out with my tears.
If waters cannot, (Duke) I bind thy rage
With this strong charm, and this read over that spell,
And let thy hard breast grow more flexible.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Where is Iouinelli; and that bastard crew
Of my false friends?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Beheaded.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: They have their due.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: The ring I gave her, and her hand: old man, --
Where is the old Friar delivered these?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: He is gon.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Make after him, it is some delusion.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: It is no delusion (father) am I the ground
Of this your quarrel, which must both confound
If you go on: your battles thus I will part,
The first blow given, shall run clean through my heart.
O noble constant maid, forgive my wrongs,
The warmth of heaven to a pining spring
Cannot such comfort give as thy glad presence
Does to my bosom.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Will you fight or no?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: It were madness to wish storms when fair winds blow:
Will you your faith yet keep?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Inviolate.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Then here end all my wars.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And all my hate.
Hast all these Friars up to the Abbey walls,
And with shrill voices, this our peace proclaim,
Stay holy father: Bohor, See you this done.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Vengeance, I have now lost more than I have won.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I shall go scot free Lurchall.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Passing well?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They do not smell me, yet myself I smell.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Why sends your Highness, thus these Friars to play
Your heralds parts in publishing this peace?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p:
There is in it a riddle (uncle) which by none but by
these Friars only, can be done. --
sp.l: So: are you mounted? Sing now.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Sing.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Yes sing,
Like Swans before your deaths: there you all shall die,
Give fire to this most damned priory.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Alacke for pity!

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Father, but for thee,
Thunder from heaven had (long ere this) to dust
Grinded these hellish buildings: that hand was just,
Which struck your vicious Prior, so is our doom,
That Synagogue of devils, let fire consume.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: But means the King that I shall burn here too?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou? the grand villain, give him a villains due.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am no Friar, see I am poor Barteruile.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How? Barteruile?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: He lies the slave is a Turk.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A Christian by this hand, Your officer.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The city canker, the courts cozener,
A devil in shape of man.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Half that I have
I freely give, so you my life will save.
I will lend your Highness thirty thousand chequines.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Ten Kingdoms cannot buy thee; were there ten hells
Thou art damned in all, 'sdeath! fie that house of devils.

sp.speaker: 3. Diu.
sp.l: Do: let us not want light to set forth our Revels.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: King, little dost thou know, whom (all this while)
Thy court, this Convent, and this Barteruile,
Have entertained: of hell, three Spirits we are.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Sent to catch souls for Pluto, our Prince and master.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Defend us heavens.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Thyself hast burst those bands
In which I once held thee: these are in our hands.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
If you be right Sergeants, for money you will let me
go. five thousand Crowns I will give but to go home.

sp.speaker: All. 3.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I will put in four brokers to be my bail: I hope they will be taken.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Yes as thou art, (to hell,) you dog leave howling.
This pile of green young devils, needs no fire
Of mortals kindling to consume, these frames,
You shall with us to hell ride, all in flames.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Catch.

sp.speaker: Au. 3.
sp.l: Come.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Let every spirit his own prize bear.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: They are so heavy with sin, they will soon be there.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Away then and be damned, would you all were here.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Oooh -- Sink down, above flames.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Immortal thanks for our deliverance:
Race to the ground those walls: no stone shall stand,
To tell such place was ever in our land,
What wealth can there be found, give to the poor,
Another house we will build and thee restore,
To former virginity: weep not for these ruins,
Thou shalt from us have honours. Here we begin
Our reign anew, which golden threads shall spin,
Justice shall henceforth sit upon our throne,
And virtue be your Kings companion.
War here resigns his black and horrid stage
To sportful Hymen, God of Marriage.

div1.stage: Exeunt. The play ending, as they goe off, from vnder" the ground in seuerall places, rise vp spirits, to them enter, leaping in great ioy, Rufman, Shacklesoule, and Lurchall, discouering behind a curten, Rauillac, Guy Faulx, Barteruile, a Prodigall, standing in their torments.

sp.speaker: Omn., Spir.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Omn., Dam.
sp.l: Torments inutterable! O! damned for nothing?

sp.speaker: Rauill.
sp.l: Terrors incomprehensible.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Back: ye are blown up else.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Whooh: hot, hot, hot, -- drink, -- I am heart-burnt.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: One drop, a bit.

sp.speaker: Faul.
sp.l: Now, now, now.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
I am parboiled, I am stewed, I am sod in a kettle of brimstone,
pottage. -- it scalds, -- it scalds, -- it scalds, -- it scalds -- whooh

sp.speaker: Diu.
sp.p: Ha ha ha:

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: But one half crom, a little little drop, a bit.

sp.speaker: Faul.
sp.p:
Towers, towers, towers, towers, pinnacles and towers,
battlements and pinnacles, steeples, abbeys, churches and
old chimneys.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: S'wounds drink, shall I choake in mine Inn? drink.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Drink, drink, O! one drop, one drop, to cool us.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: So many tapsters in hell, and none fill drink here:

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ball no more, you shall be liquored.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Why art thou damned to the horrors of one hell,
Yet feelest ten thousand.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Wherefore is thy soul
Made sensible of tortures which (each minute)
Kill thee ten thousand times, yet canst not die?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Some sack.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Why for a few sins that are long hence past,
Must I feele torments that shall ever last? Ever ever.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let the sack be mulled.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Why is the devil,
(If man be born good) suffered to make him evil?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Man is an ass, if he sit broiling thus in the glass-house
Without drink: two links of my chain for a three-half penny
bottle of mother consciences Ale: drink.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: One drop of puddle water to cool us

div1.stage: Enter Shacklesoule with a burning torch, and a long knife, Lurchall with a handfull of Snakes, A third spirit with a ladle full of molten gold, All three make a stand, laughing.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Leave howling and be damned.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Here is drink for thee royal villain.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Is it not good!
For blood thou hast thirsted, and thy drink is blood.
Strikes it so cold to thy heart? here is that shall warm thee.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Damnation, suries, fire-brands. --

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: One drop of moisture, but one crumb.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Art hungry, eat this adder: dry? Suck this Snake.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Suck and be damned thyself: I will starve first. Away

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Is not this all waters? Ruby water, some Ruby water,
Or else a bottle of postern water to save charges, or else a
Thimble-full of lemon water, to cool my stomach.

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: The ruby is swilled up all, here is lemon, down with it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Foh, the great devil or else some Aqua-vita woman
has made water, It scalds me.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Oooh.

sp.speaker: Diu.
sp.p: Ha ha ha. --

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p:
Hell grins to hear this roaring: where is this black
child of fathomless perdition? rarest devil
sp.l: That ever hold in Barathrum? here, (dear pupil)
Of a new damnations stamp, Saucer-eyed Lucifer,
Has drunk to thee this deep infernal bowl off,
Would pledge his ugliness?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Reach it me.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Choake with it.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Give fire, blow all the world up.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Bounce: it is done. Ha ha ha. --

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I shall be grinded into dust; It falls: I am mad.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: I am mad, I am mad.

sp.speaker: All 4.
sp.l: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Others.
sp.l: Ho ho ho. --

div1.stage: Enter Pluto, attended by Minos, Aeacus, and Rhadimanth, and 3. Faries.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Fetch whips of poisoned steel, strung with gloving wires.
And lash these saucy hell-hounds: duck their souls,
Nine times to the bottom of our brimstone lakes,
From whence up pull them by their singed hair,
Then hang them in ropes of ice nine times frozen over:
Are they scarce hot in hell, and must they roar?
What holiday is this? That here is such grinning, ha!
Is hell a dancing School? ye are in extremes,
Snoring, or else horn mad? Who are set on shore,
On this vast land of horror, that it resounds,
With laughter stead of shrikes, who are come to our bounds? ha!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Dread Lord of this lower tortary, to thy Jail
Have we thy busy Catch-polls (prisoners) brought
Souls, for whose coming all hell long hath sought.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Their names: Is Ward and Dantziker then come?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Yes: Dantziker is come.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Where is the dutch Schellum? where is hells factor! ha?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Charon has bound him for a thousand years,
To tug at his oar: he scoured the Seas so well,
Charon will make him ferryman of hell.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: Where is Ward?

sp.speaker: Rush.
sp.l: The Merchants are not piled nor pulled enough,
They are yet but shaven, when they are flayed, he will come.
And bring to hell fat booties of rich thieves,
A crew of swearers and drinkers the best that lives.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ward is not ripe for damming yet.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Who is it then?
Cutlar the Sergeant: ha! he come.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Yes Pluto:
Cutlar has been here long, sent in by a carman,
But his stern looks the fiends did so displease,
Bound hand and foot, he howls in little ease,
Having only mace to comfort him: he does yell,
And rave, because he cannot rest in hell.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: It is not for him, that we this holiday hold.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: The bawd of Shorditch, Is that hell-cat come?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: No: but she has been a long time launching forth,
In a Rosa-solis-barke.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Devils! Who is it then?
Mall Cutpurse is she come?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Our cousin come? No.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: It is not yet fit Mall Cutpurse here should howl,
She has been too late a sore-tormented soul.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Where is our daughter? ha? Is she idle?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: No.
She was beating hemp in bridewell to choke thieves,
Therefore to spare this she-ramp she beseeches,
Till like herself all women wear the breeches.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mall Cutpurse plies her task and cannot come.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: For whom then is this wild Shrove tuesday kept?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: See King of gloomy shades what souls resort,
To this thy most just, and least-fying court.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Stay, since our Jail is with brave-fellows stored,
Bid Charon that no more yet come aboard.
Seeing our Judges of hell here likewise are
Sit: call a Sessions: set the souls to a bar.
Minos (the just: ) Rhadamanth (the temperate.)
And Aeacus (the severe,) each take his state.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Not an officer here?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A Fury.

sp.speaker: 3. Iud.
sp.l: Make an Oyes?

sp.speaker: Fury.
sp.p:
Oyes! All manner of souls, if they love their own
quietness, keep out of hell, unless they have horrible business
at this infernal sessions, upon pain of being damnably
plagued for their lustiness. Back there, let those shackled rascals
show their faces.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Room here, we must come into the court.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What damned fiends are those dare make this noise?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: A Jury of Brokers impanelled, and deeply sworn,
To pass on all the villains in hell.

sp.speaker: Rhad.
sp.l: evil-conscience be their keeper.

sp.speaker: Fury.
sp.l: Look to the Jury: evil-conscience look to the Brokers.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Now proceed.

sp.speaker: AEac.
sp.l: Stay, let the King of Ghosts have first a view
Of those who are doomed to pains horrid, but new
Then produce those who came to your prison untried.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Peace there.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Here is one, hells tortures does deride. -- Rauillac.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Arraign me, rend me piecemeal, I will confess nothing.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Peace, thou shalt ball thy throat out.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Merciless hangmen! to tyrannize over so brave a Roman spirit.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Ho, ho, what country devil is this?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Thine own.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: A french.
The eagerest bloodhound that ever came from thence;
Is there a King to be murdered, whilst he does stand
Colossus-like, supporting a whole land,
And when by his fall that Land most fears a wrack,
Send forth this devil; his name is Rauillac.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p:
Rauillac: I am Rauillac, that laughs at tortures,
spurns at death, defies all mercy: gibbets, racks, fires, pincers,
scalding oil, wild-horses, I spit in the face of all.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p:
No: were my tongue torn out with burning flesh-books,
Fames one thousand tongues shall thunder out Rauillacs name,
extol it, eternise it, Chronicle it! Canonise it: O!

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
Down with this devil to the dungeon, there let him
howl.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Worlds shall applaud my Act, and crown my soul.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Another.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Come, you lean dog.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: One drop, a bit.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What is he? what starvelings this?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: One that lacks a medicine for hunger: I am fallen away.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: From heaven.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: To the common Jail with him.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: He must feed on beggaries basket: leave balling serra.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Shall I be undone for a little drink.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No, thou art undone for drinking.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Statue him away --
What was he when he lived.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A prodigal:
Who (in one year,) spent on whores, fools and slaves,
An Armies maintenance, now begs for cromes, and raves
To see his sumptuous buildings, pastures, woods,
That stood in uplands, drowned in Rhenish floods.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Is here all?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: All! No, the Arch-hell-hound is here.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What Peter Goner's this?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Speak softly, within an inch of giving fire, within an inch.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Had all thy gray devils in their highest lust sat,
To have littered furies, they could not have begot.
One to match this: in the dark he groped damnation,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Now, now.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Digged cellars to find where hell stood and has found it
There was but one villainy unborn, and he crowned it.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p:
So: all the billets lie close; glorious bonfire? pontifical
bonfire; brave heads to contrive this, gallant souls to
conspire in it, resolute hand to seal this with my blood,
through fire, through flint; ha, ha, ha, whither fly myself to
heaven, friends to honour, none to the halter, enemies to
massacre, ha ha, dismal tragical-Comedy now?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What does he?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: As he thinks, giving fire to powder;
Never in any land could devils have found, such walks,
As he was beating out.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: His name.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Guy Faulx.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Who calls? damnation stops throat.

sp.speaker: 3. Iud.
sp.l: Let it stop thine.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Am I betrayed? give fire, now, now, give fire.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: To burn thine own soul villain.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Pay him his hire:
He has a desperate rascals face.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Had his plot taken fire,
One realm before any other had doomsday seen,
Kings who in tombs lay at rest had wakened been,
He was within 12. hours of hewing down
A whole land at one blow, and at once drown.
In a flood of flames, and Ark-royal with his whole fleet,
Of nobility and clergy: in a leaden-sheet
Law and her children had been hotly wrapped;
Millions ere this had in our jail been clapped,
For damned Arts not known now, which had then
Been rife, but now lie dead ( the Acts with the men.)

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Make much of this our ningle: for the rest
Deliver them to our head-hangman.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: In a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Min:
sp.l: How applauds Pluto
Our ingenious tortures, and most rigorous doom?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p:
Minos, thy doom is just; -- But your all-faced
Caitiffs.
sp.l: What fish in your infernal Nets, Drew you up
In the Naples Court, City, and Friary?
We charged you sail thither: Is mischiefs River there dry?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: Dry, No: Fat preys for hell we all did meet,
In Court, City, Country, Nay, in every street,
In every house, within-him, and without-him.
He that wore best clothes, had some Devil about him:
Courtiers from Naples hither in shoals are come,
Some for Ambition, for Flattery, and Envy some:
Some, who (each meal) eat subjects up, and wore,
Whole Families in their shoo-strings, such, and others more,
Being here, have been examining ( ever since
They came) by Hells-clarke, (spotted-Conscience.)

sp.speaker: Min:
sp.l: Till the next Sessions, these we must defer.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: None come from the City, so many bad being there!

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: Yes, (King of endless horror) see who is here: Barteruile

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Rich-me in hell! they are welcome, what is the graybeard

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.p:
One that can buy thee and ten such as thou art of
thy Sea-coal-pits here. Is not this Newcastle?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No covetous wretch: it is Hell, thy black-souls prison.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: Soul in prison! I never had any soul to speak of.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: Now thou shalt find thou hast one.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: Can Angels Bail me?

sp.speaker: Min:
sp.l: Not all the wealth which the worlds back does bear
Can Bail thy wretched soul hence, Now it is here.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: A thousand Pounds. --

sp.speaker: Fur:
sp.l: Where is it fool?

sp.speaker: Rhad:
sp.l: Thy wealths now gone,
Thy hands still catch at bags, but they gripe none.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: What is this? --

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: AEac.
sp.l: Air, shadows, things Imaginary:
That is thy Torment now, which was thy Glory.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.p:
If you give me bags full of Saw-dust, in stead of money,
my Ghost shall walk.

sp.speaker: 3. Iud:
sp.l: To thy grim Father of Hell.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, to my old brother, Sir Achitophell Pinch-gut shall I: shall I?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Hence with him the Churl is mad:
In Lethes-flood drowned all the wealth he had.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
My chain, Let me hang in chains, so it be my
Gold chain; Thieves, thieves, thieves. --

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Throw him head-long into our boiling-lake,
Where molten Gold runs.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: His thirst it cannot slake,
Seas could not quench his dropsy: Gold to get
He would hang a City, starve a Country. Even yet
Raves he for Bonds and encumbers: to save whole soul,
( though he fed none living) Saw-sages were his dole.
A confused noise to come pressing in.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: What coil is that?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p:
It is a burning zeal must consume the wicked, and
therefore I will not be kept out, but will chastise and correct the foul Fiend.

sp.speaker: 3. Iud.
sp.p: What is this black Incubus?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: An Arch-great Puritan once.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha! How! a Puritan?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: An Arch-great Puritan! How comes thy soul so little?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: I did exercise too much with a lively Spirit.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Are there any more of his Synagogue?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Yes, a whole Hoy-full are Landed.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Are they all so black as he is?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Worse.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Sirrah, why being a Puritan is your soul so black?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p:
We were all smoked out of our own Country, and
sent to Rotterdam.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: How camest thou lame and crooked, why dost halt?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p:
All the brethren and sisters for the better part are
crooked, and halt: for my own part, I never went upright.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: And yet a puritan? hence with him.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Alacke!
How can I choose but halt, go lame, and crooked?
When I pulled a whole church down upon my backe.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Hence with him, he will pull all hell down too.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Let in the brethren, to confound this wicked assembly,

sp.speaker: 3. Iud.
sp.l: Thrust him out at hell gates.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: They will confound our kingdom,
If here they get but footing: rise therefore, away;
Keep the Jury of brokers till our next court day.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Adjourn this.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: O yes! Sessions is deferred
Because of Puritans, Hell cannot be cleared.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Set forward to our Hall paved all with brass,
Judges we thank you: let our officers drink,
In the bottom of hells cellar, for their good service.
Since to this height our Empire up you rear,
Hell shall hold triumphs, and ( that is done, ) prepare,
Again to walk your circuits over the earth,
Souls are hells Subjects, and their groans our mirth.

sp.speaker: Epilogue.
sp.l: If it be not good, the Devil is in it, (they say,)
The Devil was in it, this then is no good play
By that conclusion, but hereby is meant,
If for so many nones, and midnights spent
To reap three hours of mirth, our harvest-seed
Lies still and rot. The Devil in it then indeed:
Much Labour, Art, and Wit, make up a Play
As it does a Ship, yet both are cast away,
(When bravely they have past the humorous Seas)
At landing, What black fates curseth both these?
Sail it, or sink it, now it is forth, and near
The Haven at which it longs to arrive: if there
It suffers wrack, the spitefuller Rocks shoot forth,
Yet none may bring it home lade with much worth.
By your wonted gentle gale, (sweet as the Balm,)
Or by extending fair liberal Palm.
To fan away all storms, if you see it lowers,
The air shall ring thanks, but the glory is yours.
